{{EngvarB|date=January 2019}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2019}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Ryan Sessegnon | image = Ryan Sessegnon 2017.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Sessegnon playing for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in 2017 | fullname = Kouassi Ryan Sessegnon{{cite web |url=https://www.thefa.com/~/media/files/thefaportal/governance-docs/registrations/player-registration---july-2016.ashx |title=List of Players Registered as Scholars in Accordance with Rule C.3 Between 01/07/2016 and 31/07/2016 |publisher=The Football Association |format=PDF |page=51 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161112083038/http://www.thefa.com/~/media/files/thefaportal/governance-docs/registrations/player-registration---july-2016.ashx |archivedate=12 November 2016 |deadurl=yes}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|2000|05|18|df=y}}{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/under17/season=2016/teams/player=250097165/index.html |title=Ryan Sessegnon |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=10 August 2016}} | birth_place = [[Roehampton]], England | height = {{height|ft=5|in=10}}{{cite web |url=https://www.fulhamfc.com/player-profiles/ryan-sessegnon |title=Ryan Sessegnon |publisher=Fulham F.C. |accessdate=24 May 2017}} | position = [[Midfielder#Winger|Left winger]] / [[left back]] | currentclub = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] | clubnumber = 3 | youthyears1 = 2008–2016 | youthclubs1 = [[Fulham F.C. Academy|Fulham]] | years1 = 2016– | clubs1 = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] | caps1 = 94 | goals1 = 22 | nationalyears1 = 2015–2016 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 10 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalyears2 = 2016 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 5 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2016–2017 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 14 | nationalgoals3 = 4 | nationalyears4 = 2018– | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]]{{cite web |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslTmU21pg4.html |title=England's matches: The under 21's: 2010–20 |website=England Football Online |date=15 November 2018 |accessdate=10 December 2018}}
{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45479514 |title=Latvia U21 1–2 England U21 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 September 2018 |accessdate=10 December 2018}}
{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46283328 |title=Denmark U21 1–5 England U21 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 November 2018 |accessdate=10 December 2018}} | nationalcaps4 = 7 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | club-update = 08:41, 10 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 21:33, 1 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Kouassi Ryan Sessegnon''' (born 18 May 2000) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[left back]] or [[Midfielder#Winger|left winger]] for {{English football updater|Fulham}} club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21 national team]]. After eight years in the club's youth teams, Sessegnon was promoted to the Fulham senior team in 2016, and made an instant impact on the team, and was considered a club superstar in his [[2016–17 EFL Championship|debut season]], which saw his team finish sixth in the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] and qualify for the [[2017 Football League play-offs|promotion play-offs]], where they were defeated in the semi-finals by [[Reading F.C.|Reading]]. In his second season, Sessegnon renewed his form, and helped Fulham achieve promotion to the Premier League via the play-offs. Sessegnon has previously represented his country at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]] and [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] levels. ==Early life== Sessegnon was born in [[Roehampton]], London, and has a twin brother, [[Steven Sessegnon|Steven]], who also plays for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].{{cite news |last=Singer |first=Jonny |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3283256/Fulham-s-future-looking-bright-toppling-big-guns-win-Premier-League-s-U16-International-Cup-patience-key-success-says-academy-coach-Kevin-Betsy.html |title=Fulham's future looking bright after toppling big guns to win the Premier League's U16 International Cup... but patience is key to success, says academy coach Kevin Betsy |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=21 October 2015 |accessdate=14 September 2016}}{{Unreliable source?|date=May 2017}} Sessegnon is a distant cousin of the Beninese international footballer [[Stéphane Sessègnon]].{{cite news |last=Collomosse |first=Tom |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/fulham-teen-ryan-sessegnon-can-rise-to-challenge-as-chelsea-tottenham-and-europe-look-on-a3451296.html |title=Fulham teen Ryan Sessegnon can rise to challenge as Chelsea, Tottenham and Europe look on |newspaper=London Evening Standard |date=27 January 2017 |accessdate=7 June 2017}} ==Club career== ===Fulham=== Sessegnon joined Fulham in 2008 in their under-nine team. ====2016–17 season==== On 9 August 2016, Sessegnon made his first-team debut in an [[EFL Cup]] match against [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] aged 16 years and 81 days.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36949840 |title=Leyton Orient 2–3 Fulham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 August 2016 |accessdate=10 August 2016}} On 16 August, he made his league debut in a [[EFL Championship|Championship]] match against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in a 1–1 draw.{{cite web |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/116sde3jdhs0b1u5ajmem29p05/title/wood-strikes-to-clinch-late-point |title=Wood strikes to clinch late point |publisher=Leeds United F.C. |date=16 August 2016 |accessdate=16 August 2016}} On 20 August, he scored his first professional goal in a league match against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], becoming the first professional footballer in the English leagues to have been born in the 2000s to score a goal in a first-team game and the youngest player ever to have scored in a Championship match.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37067348 |title=Fulham 2–2 Cardiff |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 August 2016 |accessdate=22 August 2016}}{{cite news |last=Shode |first=Lekan |url=http://www.90min.com/posts/3666315-man-united-enter-transfer-race-with-liverpool-to-sign-fulham-starlet-ryan-sessegnon |title=Man United Enter Transfer Race With Liverpool to Sign Fulham Starlet Ryan Sessegnon |publisher=90min |date=24 August 2016 |accessdate=14 September 2016}} He scored the winner on his [[FA Cup]] debut, also against Cardiff, on 8 January, becoming one of the youngest goalscorers in the history of the competition.{{Cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/fulhams-16yearold-ryan-sessegnon-marks-fa-cup-debut-with-goal-to-become-one-of-the-competitions-a3435396.html |title=Fulham's 16-year-old starlet Sessegnon marks FA Cup debut with a goal |date=8 January 2017 |newspaper=London Evening Standard |accessdate=1 July 2017}} On 11 March, Sessegnon scored twice in an away match against eventual league champions [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]],{{Cite web |url=https://www.fulhamfc.com/first-team/2016_2017/league/away/newcastle-united |title=Newcastle United 1–3 Fulham |publisher=Fulham F.C. |accessdate=1 July 2017}} with former Newcastle player [[Alan Shearer]] praising his performance as "brilliant".{{Cite web |url=https://twitter.com/alanshearer/status/840613425080336384 |title=He was brilliant, as was his captain Tom Cairney |last=Shearer |first=Alan |date=11 March 2017 |website=@alanshearer|access-date=1 July 2017}} In total, Sessegnon made 30 appearances in all competitions, including in the second leg of Fulham's play-off semi-final defeat against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]],{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39853033 |title=Reading 1–0 Fulham (agg: 2–1) |date=16 May 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=1 July 2017}} scoring seven goals, and was named in the [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)#Championship 8|PFA Championship Team of the Year]],{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39648483 |title=PFA teams of the year: Chelsea and Tottenham dominate Premier League XI |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 April 2017 |accessdate=5 May 2018}} the youngest player ever included.{{Cite news |url=http://www.squawka.com/news/confirmed-brighton-dominate-cship-toty-but-one-newcastle-inclusion-has-fans-talking/936519#M2G4Jg4prFy4oRl2.97 |title=Ryan Sessegnon becomes youngest ever player in PFA Championship Team of the Year |work=Squawka Football News |accessdate=1 July 2017}} Media interest in Sessegnon grew as his debut season progressed. In February 2017, Italian newspaper ''[[La Gazzetta dello Sport]]'' ranked Sessegnon as one of the top 30 Under-20s players in Europe,{{Cite news |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/2925930/marcus-rashford-tom-davies-ryan-sessegnon-top-30-under-20s-europe/ |title=Marcus Rashford, Tom Davies and Ryan Sessegnon named in the top 30 Under-20s stars in Europe |date=22 February 2017 |newspaper=The Sun |accessdate=1 July 2017}}{{Unreliable source?|date=July 2017}} while in May 2017, ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' named him as the 19th-best under-20 player in world football.{{Cite news |url=https://www.si.com/planet-futbol/2017/05/16/top-20-under-20-world-soccer |title=Top 20 Under 20: The world's best rising soccer stars |last=Lyttleton |first=Ben |work=Sports Illustrated |accessdate=1 July 2017}} Fulham striker [[Neeskens Kebano]] called him "the future of English football",{{Cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/fulhams-ryan-sessegnon-the-future-10405372 |title=Sessegnon 'the future of English football' says Fulham teammate before playoffs |last=Walters |first=Mike |date=11 May 2017 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |accessdate=1 July 2017}} with teammate [[Stefan Johansen]] saying it was "99% certain he will be one of the top left-backs in the world".{{Cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11681/10767778/ryan-sessegnon-in-focus-fulham-teenager-is-the-next-english-star |title=Ryan Sessegnon in focus: Fulham teenager is the next English star |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=1 July 2017}} As the summer transfer window approached, interest was reported from numerous [[Premier League]] clubs, including [[Everton F.C.|Everton]],{{Cite news |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/everton-latest-club-linked-fulhams-12715620 |title=Everton the latest club to be linked with Ryan Sessegnon |last=O'Donovan |first=Ryan |date=9 March 2017 |work=getwestlondon |accessdate=1 July 2017}} [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]{{Cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/liverpool-plotting-summer-move-fulhams-12944494 |title=Liverpool plotting summer move for Fulham's Ryan Sessegnon |last=Pearce |first=James |date=26 April 2017 |newspaper=Liverpool Echo |accessdate=1 July 2017}} and [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]],{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/06/01/manchester-united-keen-sign-fulham-wonderkid-ryan-sessegnon/ |title=Manchester United keen to sign Fulham wonderkid Ryan Sessegnon |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=1 July 2017}} as well as [[Bundesliga]] sides [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] and [[RB Leipzig]],{{Cite news |url=https://www.dreamteamfc.com/c/archives/news-gossip/186636/fulham-newcastle-ryan-sessegnon/ |title=Who is the English 16-year-old who scored twice against Newcastle? |date=11 March 2017 |work=Dream Team FC |accessdate=1 July 2017}} with Sessegnon potentially available for a compensation fee of £2 million{{Cite web |url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/06/01/jose-mourinho-personally-requests-manchester-united-sign-ryan-sessegnon-6678646/ |title=Jose Mourinho personally rates teenage star and requests Man Utd sign him |last=Metro.co.uk |first=Metro Sport Reporter for |date=1 June 2017 |website=Metro |accessdate=1 July 2017}} as [[The Football Association|Football Association]] rules meant he could not sign professional terms until his 17th birthday on 18 May 2017.{{Cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/~/media/Files/TheFAPortal/governance-docs/registrations/fa-rule-c---relating-to-players.ashx. |title=The website for the English football association, the Emirates FA Cup and the England football team |last=Association |first=The Football |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=1 July 2017}} However, on 28 June 2017, it was announced Sessegnon had signed his first professional contract with Fulham, committing him to the club until 2020.{{cite web |url=https://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2017/june/28/sess-turns-pro |title=Sess Turns Pro |publisher=Fulham F.C. |accessdate=1 July 2017}} Sessegnon cited the likelihood of playing regularly in the first team as his reason, saying, "Last season I got a lot of opportunities so I want to continue that. When you are young you just want to play as many games as you can."{{Cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/tottenham-transfer-news-ryan-sessegnon-reveals-why-he-snubbed-premier-league-clubs-to-sign-new-a3575996.html |title=Ryan Sessegnon reveals why he snubbed Tottenham and Manchester United |date=29 June 2017 |newspaper=London Evening Standard |accessdate=1 July 2017}} ====2017–18 season==== On 28 July 2017, Fulham announced that Sessegnon would wear the number 3 shirt, moving from his previous number 30.{{Cite web |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2017/july/28/squad-numbers |title=Squad Numbers |publisher=Fulham F.C. |accessdate=31 July 2017}} He scored his first goal of the season in a 1–1 draw with Cardiff on 9 September.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41132796 |title=Fulham 1–1 Cardiff City |date=9 September 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=14 September 2017}} In November 2017, ''[[FourFourTwo]]'' included Sessegnon in their 100 Best Teenagers in the World list, comparing him with [[Ashley Cole]] and [[David Alaba]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/my/features/fourfourtwos-100-best-teenagers-world-2017-40-21 |title=FourFourTwo's 100 Best Teenagers in the World 2017: 40–21 |date=9 November 2017 |work=FourFourTwo |accessdate=23 November 2017}} On 21 November 2017, Sessegnon marked his 50th appearance for Fulham by scoring his first professional hat-trick in a 5–4 away victory against [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41978135 |title=Sheffield United 4–5 Fulham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 November 2017}} – becoming the first seventeen-year-old to score a hat-trick in the top four tiers of English league football since [[Dele Alli]] in 2014.{{Cite web |url=https://twitter.com/OptaJoe/status/933257770790404096 |title=17 – Ryan Sessegnon was the first 17-year-old to score a hat-trick within the top four tiers of English league football since Dele Alli in March 2014 (Notts County 1–3 MK Dons in League One). Exciting.pic.twitter.com/Yax86Qt6kL |last=OptaJoe |date=22 November 2017 |website=@OptaJoe |accessdate=23 November 2017}} After netting six goals in January 2018, courtesy of braces against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] and [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]], Sessegnon was named [[Professional Footballers' Association|PFA]]{{Cite web |url=https://www.thepfa.com/thepfa/pfa-fans-player-of-the-month/january-pfa-championship-fans-player-of-the-month-ryan-sessegnon |title=Ryan Sessegnon voted the PFA Bristol Street Motors Player of the Month |publisher=Professional Footballers' Association |accessdate=10 February 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180211072324/https://www.thepfa.com/thepfa/pfa-fans-player-of-the-month/january-pfa-championship-fans-player-of-the-month-ryan-sessegnon |archivedate=11 February 2018 |deadurl=yes}} and [[EFL Championship Player of the Month|Championship Player of the Month]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/news/2018/february/player-of-the-month-ryan-sessegnon---fulham/ |title=EFL Official Website Player of the Month: Ryan Sessegnon – Fulham |accessdate=10 February 2018}} On 19 February 2018, Sessegnon was named tenth in the most promising under 20 prospects in the whole of Europe. Sessegnon featured in a prestigious list by CIES with the likes of [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] goalkeeper [[Gianluigi Donnarumma]] featuring in 1st place and [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] striker [[Kylian Mbappé]] in 3rd place.{{cite news |title=Gianluigi Donnarumma: AC Milan keeper named top under-20 European prospect |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43115781 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 February 2018}} In April 2018 he was nominated for the EFL Championship Player of the Season and Young Player of the Season awards.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43641225 |title=EFL awards: Tom Cairney, Ruben Neves & Ryan Sessgenon on Championship shortlist |date=4 April 2018 |accessdate=4 April 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport}} He also became the first Championship player to be nominated for the [[PFA Young Player of the Year]] award. On 15 April, Sessegnon won an unprecedented five awards when he was named [[Football League Awards#2018 awards|Championship Player of the Season]], Young Player of the Season, [[Football League Apprentice of the Year|Apprentice of the Year]], and named in the Team of the Season and EFL Club Developed XI.{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/fulham-wonderkid-ryan-sessegnon-wins-12371190 |title=Fulham wonderkid Ryan Sessegnon wins FIVE gongs at EFL awards including Championship Player of the Year |last=Whaling |first=James |work=Mirror |date=15 April 2018 |accessdate=16 April 2018}} Fulham finished the league season in third place, allowing them to advance to the [[EFL Championship play-offs|play-offs]], where Sessegnon helped his side secure a place in the play-off final by scoring the opening goal and assisting the game-winning goal in the semi-final second leg against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]].{{cite web |last1=Dean |first1=Sam |title=Ryan Sessegnon blows Derby County away to fire Fulham into play-off final |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/05/14/ryan-sessegnon-fires-fulham-play-off-final-derby-county-blown/ |website=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=14 May 2018}} On 26 May 2018, Sessegnon assisted [[Tom Cairney]]'s 23rd minute goal in a 1–0 win against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in the [[2018 EFL Championship play-off Final|Championship play-off final]] at [[Wembley Stadium|Wembley]] to secure promotion to the [[Premier League]] for Fulham.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/may/26/aston-villa-fulham-championship-play-off-final-match-report |title=Fulham promoted to Premier League after play-off win over Aston Villa |work=The Guardian |accessdate=24 October 2018 |date=26 May 2018}} ====2018–19 season==== Sessegnon made his first ever [[Premier League]] appearance on 11 August 2018, the opening day of the new league campaign, which resulted in a 2–0 defeat to an established [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] at [[Craven Cottage]].{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/match/38310 |title=Fulham v Crystal Palace, 2018/19 |publisher=Premier League |date=11 August 2018 |accessdate=24 November 2018}} On 20 October 2018, the English winger scored his first Premier League goal in a 4–2 away loss to [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], becoming the first player born in the 2000s to score in the competition.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45930086 |title=Premier League stats: Ryan Sessegnon and the millennium babies making an impact |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 October 2018 |date=21 October 2018}} He made his 100th appearance for the club on 8 December, starting in a 4–1 league loss to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].{{cite news |url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/1055752/Man-Utd-Premier-League-TV-Stream-Fulham-Score-Goals-Jose-Mourinho-Paul-Pogba-Latest |title=Man Utd 4–1 Fulham AS IT HAPPENED: Romelu Lukaku scores first home goal since March |publisher=Express |last=Anderson |first=Jamie |date=8 December 2018 |accessdate=1 January 2019}} ==International career== In 2016, Sessegnon played up an age group to represent England in the [[2016 UEFA European Under-17 Championship|U17 Euros]].{{cite web |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2016/may/04/duo-on-england-duty |title=Duo on England duty |publisher=Fulham F.C. |date=4 May 2016 |accessdate=10 August 2016}} He scored his first goal for [[England national under-19 football team|England Under-19s]] against [[Luxembourg national under-19 football team|Luxembourg]] in a [[UEFA European Under-19 Championship|European Under-19 Championship]] qualifier on 10 November 2016, scoring the second goal in a 2–0 win.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/nov/10/england-u19s-luxembourg-report-101116 |title=The website for the English football association, the Emirates FA Cup and the England football team |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=1 July 2017}} On 26 June 2017, Sessegnon was named in the final 18-man squad for the [[2017 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|Euro U19s finals]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/jun/26/england-u19-squad-for-euros-260617 |title=Young Lions squad for U19 Euro |last=Association |first=The Football |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=1 July 2017}} He went on to score three goals, including two in a 4–1 win over [[Germany national youth football team|Germany]],{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/jul/10/ryan-sessegnon-post-germany-100717 |title=Young Lions ace Ryan Sessegnon says first-team action has helped him at Euros finals |publisher=The Football Association |date=10 July 2017 |accessdate=13 July 2017}} finishing the tournament as joint-top scorer{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/season=2017/statistics/index.html |title=Under-19 – Statistics |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=15 July 2017}} as England were crowned champions for the first time.{{Cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/england-win-euro-u19-championship-as-lukas-nmecha-winner-downs-portgual-in-final-a3588831.html |title=England win Euro Under-19 Championship with win over Portugal |newspaper=London Evening Standard |accessdate=15 July 2017}} He was subsequently included in the [[2017 UEFA European Under-19 Championship#Team of the Tournament|team of the tournament]].{{cite web |title=2017 UEFA U19 Technical Report |url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/season=2017/technical-report/uefa-technical-team/index.html |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=5 October 2017}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 12 January 2019}} {| class=wikitable style=text-align:center |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|[[FA Cup]] !colspan=2|[[EFL Cup]] !colspan=2|Other !colspan=2|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan=3|[[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] |[[2016–17 Fulham F.C. season|2016–17]]{{soccerbase season|94024|2016|accessdate=27 December 2018}} |[[EFL Championship|Championship]] |25||5||3||2||1||0||1{{efn|name=CPO|Appearance(s) in [[EFL Championship play-offs|Championship play-offs]]}}||0||30||7 |- |[[2017–18 Fulham F.C. season|2017–18]]{{soccerbase season|94024|2017|accessdate=27 December 2018}} |Championship |46||15||1||0||2||0||3{{efn|name=CPO}}||1||52||16 |- |[[2018–19 Fulham F.C. season|2018–19]]{{soccerbase season|94024|2018|accessdate=1 January 2019}} |[[Premier League]] |20||2||1||0||2||0||colspan=2|—||23||2 |- !colspan=3|Career total !91||22||5||2||5||0||4||1||105||25 |} {{notelist}} ==Honours== '''Fulham''' *[[EFL Championship play-offs]]: [[2018 English Football League play-offs#Championship|2018]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44178427 |title=Aston Villa 0–1 Fulham |first=Phil |last=Cartwright |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 May 2018 |accessdate=26 May 2018}} '''England U19''' *[[UEFA European Under-19 Championship]]: [[2017 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|2017]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40619862 |title=European Under-19 Championship: England beat Portugal in final |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 July 2017 |accessdate=9 August 2017}} '''Individual''' *[[PFA Team of the Year]]: [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)#Championship 8|2016–17 Championship]], [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)#Championship 9|2017–18 Championship]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43808543 |title=PFA Championship Team of the Year: Wolves & Fulham trios named in line-up |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 April 2018 |accessdate=5 May 2018}} *PFA Championship Player of the Month: January 2018 *[[EFL Championship Player of the Month]]: January 2018 *UEFA European Under-19 Championship Team of the Tournament: [[2017 UEFA European Under-19 Championship#Team of the Tournament|2017]] *[[Football League Apprentice of the Year|LFE Championship Apprentice of the Year]]: [[Football League Awards#2018 Awards|2017–18]]{{Cite news |url=https://www.lfe.org.uk/news/ryan-sessegnon-receives-lfe-championship-apprentice-of-the-year-prize |title=Ryan Sessegnon Receives LFE Championship Apprentice of the Year Prize |work=LFE |accessdate=8 May 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[https://www.fulhamfc.com/player-profiles/ryan-sessegnon Profile] at the Fulham F.C. website {{distinguish|text=the Australian rules footballer, [[Callum Chambers]]}} {{EngvarB|date=December 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Calum Chambers | image = Calum Chambers cropped.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Chambers after winning the [[2014 FA Community Shield]] with [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | fullname = Calum Chambers{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=10 February 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1995|1|20|df=y}}{{Hugman|26074|accessdate=1 April 2016}} | birth_place = [[Petersfield]], England | height = {{convert|1.82|m|order=flip}}{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/4620/Calum-Chambers/overview |title=Calum Chambers: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=18 December 2017}} | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] | currentclub = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]
(on loan from [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]) | clubnumber = 5 | youthyears1 = 2002–2012 | youthclubs1 = [[Southampton F.C. Academy|Southampton]] | years1 = 2012–2014 | clubs1 = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] | caps1 = 22 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2014– | clubs2 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | caps2 = 48 | goals2 = 2 | years3 = 2016–2017 | clubs3 = → [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] (loan) | caps3 = 24 | goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2018– | clubs4 = → [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] (loan) | caps4 = 19 | goals4 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2012 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 6 | nationalgoals1 = 3 | nationalyears2 = 2012–2014 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 18 | nationalgoals2 = 2 | nationalyears3 = 2015–2017 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 22 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2014– | nationalteam4 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps4 = 3 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | club-update = 08:44, 10 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 12:25, 30 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Calum Chambers''' (born 20 January 1995) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from fellow {{English football updater|Arsenal}} club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], and the [[England national football team|England national team]]. Originally a member of [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]'s [[Southampton F.C. Academy|academy system]], Chambers was promoted to the first team at the beginning of the [[2012–13 Southampton F.C. season|2012–13]] campaign. After two seasons with the club, he moved to fellow Premier League club Arsenal. Chambers made his senior international debut for the [[England national football team|English national team]] in 2014. ==Club career== ===Southampton=== Born in [[Petersfield]], Hampshire, Chambers joined [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] at the age of seven.{{cite news |url=http://metro.co.uk/2014/07/14/who-is-arsenal-target-calum-chambers-4798262/ |title=Who is Arsenal target Calum Chambers? |author=James Phillips |newspaper=Metro |location=London |date=14 July 2014 |accessdate=3 August 2014}} He went through the ranks at the club and at the beginning of the [[2012–13 Southampton F.C. season|2012–13 season]], Chambers was revealed as one of four youth players to be promoted to the first-team.{{cite web |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/numbers-up-for-saints-318707.aspx |title=Numbers up for Saints |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=17 August 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2012}} During the pre-season period he made a number of appearances for the team, playing in the Memorial Cup against [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]],{{cite web |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/memorial-cup-report-237234.aspx?pageView=full#anchored |title=Memorial Cup − Report |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=14 July 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2012}} coming on as a second-half substitute in the matches against [[Thonon Évian Savoie F.C.|Évian Thonon Gaillard]] and [[Étoile Carouge FC|Étoile Carouge]],{{cite web |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/evian-tg-0-1-saints-report-291272.aspx?pageView=full#anchored |title=Évian TG 0–1 Saints − Report |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=21 July 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/etoile-carouge-1-4-saints-report-291269.aspx?pageView=full#anchored |title=Etoile Carouge 1–4 Saints − Report |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=18 July 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2012}} and making late appearances against [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] and [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].{{cite web |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/saints-0-1-ajax-report-275919.aspx?pageView=full#anchored |title=Saints 0–1 Ajax − Report |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=28 July 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/saints-2-0-wolves-report-292113.aspx?pageView=full#anchored |title=Saints 2–0 Wolves − Report |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=4 August 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2012}} Chambers made his full debut for Southampton on 28 August 2012 in a 4–1 win over [[Stevenage F.C.|Stevenage]] in the second round of the [[2012–13 Football League Cup|League Cup]], coming on as an 84th-minute substitute for [[Dean Hammond]] and providing the assist for the final goal of the match by [[Ben Reeves]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19340365 |title=Stevenage 1–4 Southampton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 August 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} On 31 July 2013, Chambers signed a new four-year contract with Southampton.{{cite web |title=Chambers commits to Saints |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/article/chambers-commits-to-saints-958138.aspx |publisher=Southampton F.C. |accessdate=1 August 2013 |date=31 July 2013}} He made his first-team league debut on 17 August 2013, when he played the full 90 minutes at right-back of the opening match of the [[2013–14 Premier League|2013–14]] season in a 1–0 win against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Johnston |title=West Brom 0–1 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/23644676 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 August 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} He made a total of 25 appearances for Southampton in all competitions, of which 22 were in the league, before leaving in the summer of 2014. ===Arsenal=== [[File:Calum ChambersOct2014.JPG|thumb|upright|Chambers (right) playing for [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in 2014]] On 28 July 2014, it was announced that he had signed for [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on a long-term contract for an undisclosed fee, rising to a potential £16 million with performance-related add-ons.{{cite web |title=Calum Chambers signs for Arsenal |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/20140728/calum-chambers-completes-move-to-arsenal |publisher=Arsenal F.C. |accessdate=28 July 2014 |date=28 July 2014}}{{cite news |title=Arsenal sign Calum Chambers from Southampton in deal rising to £16m |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jul/28/arsenal-sign-calum-chambers-southampton |accessdate=28 July 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=28 July 2014}} Chambers made his first appearance for Arsenal on 2 August 2014, starting in central defence in a 5–1 win against [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] in the pre-season [[Emirates Cup]] tournament.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/aug/02/arsenal-benfica-emirates-cup-match-report |title=Arsenal's Yaya Sanogo hits four in friendly rout of Benfica |date=2 August 2014 |accessdate=3 August 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London}} On 10 August, Chambers made his competitive debut for Arsenal, playing the full 90 minutes of the [[2014 FA Community Shield]] against Premier League champions [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] at [[Wembley Stadium]]. Playing at centre back instead of his usual right back position to cover for [[Per Mertesacker]], the BBC wrote on his performance against the Premier League champions that "his mature performance defied his youthful years".{{cite news |first=Mandeep |last=Sanghera |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28647186 |title=Arsenal 3–0 Manchester City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 August 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} On 16 August, Chambers played his first [[Premier League]] match for Arsenal in a 2–1 win against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{cite news |first=Saj |last=Chowdhury |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28718788 |title=Arsenal 2–1 Crystal Palace |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} He played the first European fixture of his career three days later, a goalless draw in the first leg of Arsenal's Champions League play-off away to [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]].{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |title=Besiktas 0–0 Arsenal |url=http://bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28784340 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 August 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} Following a strong start to the season, Chambers was nominated for the [[Golden Boy (award)|Golden Boy Award 2014]], alongside international teammates [[Raheem Sterling]], [[Luke Shaw]] and [[John Stones]].{{cite news |last=Richards |first=Alex |title=England pair Raheem Sterling and Calum Chambers join Adnan Januzaj in Golden Boy award nominations |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/england-pair-raheem-sterling-calum-4523237 |accessdate=28 October 2014 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |date=28 October 2014}} He scored the first senior goal of his career and registered an assist on 1 November as Arsenal beat [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] 3–0 in a Premier League home victory.{{cite news |last=Gheerbrant |first=James |title=Arsenal 3–0 Burnley |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29768015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 November 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} He was sent off for the first time in his career on 6 December, as Arsenal lost 3–2 at [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].{{cite news |last=Chowdhury |first=Saj |title=Stoke City 3–2 Arsenal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30257121 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 December 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} Chambers' appearances in the second half of the season were limited by the emergence of [[Héctor Bellerín]] at right-back.{{cite news |last=Fernandez-Abascal |first=Eduardo |title=Héctor Bellerín will 'fight' Mathieu Debuchy for Arsenal right-back slot after breakthrough season |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/hector-bellerin-will-fight-mathieu-debuchy-arsenal-right-back-slot-after-breakthrough-season-1503876 |accessdate=2 June 2015 |work=International Business Times |date=1 June 2015}} He was not in Arsenal's matchday squad when they won the [[2015 FA Cup Final]] 4–0 against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] at Wembley Stadium on 30 May.{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=Arsenal 4–0 Aston Villa |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32856754 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 May 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} Chambers began the [[2016–17 Premier League]] in the starting line-up for Arsenal and scored in a 3–4 loss against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in the first match of the season.{{cite news |last=Chowdhury |first=Saj |title=Arsenal 3–4 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37001073 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 August 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} ===Middlesbrough (loan)=== [[File:Calum Chambers*.jpg|thumb|upright|Chambers playing for [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in 2016]] On 30 August 2016, he joined fellow Premier League team [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on a season-long [[Loan (sports)|loan]].{{cite news |title=Calum Chambers: Middlesbrough sign Arsenal defender on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37218210 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 August 2016 |accessdate=19 July 2017}} ===Return to Arsenal=== Chambers made his first appearance of the [[2017–18 Arsenal F.C. season|2017–18 season]] in the 1–0 win over [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] in the [[EFL Cup]], but was substituted at half time due to injury.{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/arsenal-vs-doncaster/384183 |title=Arsenal 1–0 Doncaster |publisher=Sky Sports |date=21 September 2017 |accessdate=4 October 2017}} On 3 July 2018, Chambers signed a new long-term contract with Arsenal.{{cite web |title=Calum Chambers signs contract extension |url=https://www.arsenal.com/news/calum-chambers-signs-contract-extension |publisher=Arsenal F.C. |accessdate=3 July 2018 |date=3 July 2018}} ===Fulham (loan)=== On 7 August 2018, Chambers signed with fellow Premier League side [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on a season long loan.{{cite web |title=Calum Chambers joins Fulham on loan |url=https://www.arsenal.com/news/calum-chambers-joins-fulham-loan |accessdate=7 August 2018 |date=7 August 2018}} ==International career== Chambers made his debut for the [[England national under-17 football team|England under-17 team]] on 2 February against [[Portugal national under-17 football team|Portugal]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/All-Teams/Players/C/calum-chambers |title=Calum Chambers |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=29 August 2012}} In March, he played in all three of the team's matches in the [[2012 UEFA European Under-17 Championship elite round]], scoring their only goal of the tournament in a 1–0 win over [[Ukraine national under-17 football team|Ukraine]].{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/under17/season=2012/teams/player=250047102/index.html |title=Calum Chambers |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=29 August 2012}} On 26 September 2012, Chambers made the step up to the [[England national under-19 football team|England under-19 team]], playing the full 90 minutes in the team's 3–0 win over the [[Estonia national youth football team#Estonia National Under-19 Squad|Estonia under-19 team]] in the [[2013 UEFA European Under-19 Championship qualification|2013 UEFA European Under-19 Championship qualifying round]].{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/season=2013/matches/round=2000318/match=2009284/index.html |title=England-Estonia |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=27 September 2012}} On 28 September Chambers came on as a second-half substitute in the England under-19 team's match against the [[Faroe Islands national under-19 football team|Faroe Islands]], which England won 6–0, scoring the final goal of the match in the 84th minute.{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/season=2013/matches/round=2000318/match=2009308/index.html |title=Faroe Islands-England |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=28 September 2012}} He scored his second under-19 international goal in a 1–0 victory against [[Turkey national under-19 football team|Turkey]] on 21 March 2013.{{cite web |last=Veevers |first=Nichols |title=Chambers clinches win as England U19s head off to elite round on back of 1–0 win over Turkey |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u19s/News/2013/turkey-report-210313 |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=22 March 2013 |date=21 March 2013}} On 28 August 2014, he was named in the senior England squad for the first time, ahead of a friendly against [[Norway national football team|Norway]] and a [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying|Euro 2016 qualification match]] against [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] in September.{{cite web |title=Roy calls up four new faces for Norway and Switzerland |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/2014/aug/norway-switzerland-squad-announcement-rose-colback-delph-chambers |accessdate=28 August 2014 |publisher=The Football Association |date=28 August 2014}} He made his debut against Norway on 3 September, coming on for the last 9 minutes in place of John Stones as England won 1–0 at Wembley Stadium.{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=England 1–0 Norway |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28947896 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 September 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} Initially chosen for the [[England national under-21 football team|under-21 team]], Chambers moved into the senior squad ahead of European qualifiers against [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] and [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]] in October 2014 due to an injury to Stones.{{cite news |title=England: John Stones replaced by Calum Chambers in squad |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29497934 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 October 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} He was given his first start on his second cap, against San Marino on 9 October at Wembley Stadium, playing at right back ahead of his former Southampton teammate [[Nathaniel Clyne]].{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=England 5–0 San Marino |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29454223 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 October 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}} Chambers then dropped back down to the under-21 team in March 2015, and made his debut in a 1–0 win against [[Czech Republic national under-21 football team|Czech Republic]] in Prague.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/mar/27/czech-republic-england-under-21s-friendly-match-report |title=Tom Carroll scores winner for England Under-21s against Czech Republic |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=27 March 2015 |accessdate=28 March 2015}} He was part of the team that won the [[2016 Toulon Tournament]], their first such win for 22 years.{{cite news |title=England Under-21s win Toulon Tournament for first time in 22 years |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36410296 |accessdate=29 May 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 May 2016}} On 5 June 2017, Chambers was called up to England's squad for the [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] to be held in Poland.{{cite web |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/20170605/england-call-for-chambers-and-holding |title=England call for Chambers and Holding |publisher=Arsenal F.C. |date=5 June 2017 |accessdate=5 June 2017}} Chambers went on to play in the semi-final of the tournament where England went out on penalties to Germany.{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/season=2017/matches/round=2000646/match=2022540/index.html |title=England 2–2 Germany: Germany win 4–3 on penalties |publisher=UEFA}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{Other people|Kevin McDonald}} {{Infobox person | name = Kevin McDonald | image = ETalk2008-Kids In The Hall.jpg | caption = McDonald (center, front) with the
''[[The Kids in the Hall|Kids in the Hall]]'' cast | birth_name = Kevin Hamilton McDonald | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1961|5|16}} | birth_place = [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada | occupation = Actor, voice actor, comedian | years_active = 1988–present }} '''Kevin Hamilton McDonald''' (born May 16, 1961) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] actor, voice actor and comedian. He is known as a member of ''[[The Kids in the Hall]]'', the voice of [[List of Lilo & Stitch characters#Pleakley|Agent Pleakley]] in the [[Lilo & Stitch (franchise)|''Lilo & Stitch'' franchise]], Waffle in ''[[Catscratch]]'', Pastor Dave in ''[[That 70s Show]]'', and the Almighty Tallest Purple in ''[[Invader Zim]]''. Kevin also stars as a co-pilot in the 2011 web comedy series ''[[Papillon (TV series)|Papillon]]''. ==Early life== McDonald was born in [[Montréal]], [[Québec]], the son of Sheila and Hamilton "Hammy" McDonald, who was a dental equipment salesman.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/18/Kevin-McDonald.html|title=Kevin McDonald Biography (1961-)|website=www.filmreference.com}} He moved to [[Los Angeles, California]] at the age of seven, after his father was transferred there.{{cite web|url=http://www.kithfan.org/kith/kevin.html|title=KITHfan.org : Kids in the Hall : Kevin McDonald|website=www.kithfan.org}} His family subsequently lived in [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]] as well. McDonald has a younger sister, Sandra. During an interview on ''[[WTF with Marc Maron]]'', McDonald discussed his father's severe [[alcoholism]], which inspired the ''Kids In The Hall'' sketches "Daddy Drank" and "Girl Drink Drunk". Although he calls his mother "a wonderful woman," she was nevertheless reluctant to leave him until Kevin turned 19, when his father's drinking had escalated to two bottles of vodka daily. McDonald, his mother and sister rented an apartment, where they quietly moved their belongings "every night [after his father would] collapse on the stairs." Once they had completely moved, his parents divorced, his father lost his job, went bankrupt and lived in a homeless shelter for a year, during which he abstained from drinking (although he alleged "his roommates were drinking Drano"); coincidentally, Kevin McDonald would use the same building to rehearse with ''The Kids In The Hall'' as they were starting out on stage. His father was able to find employment at a flower shop, then an apartment and, over time, resume his career in dental equipment sales. Eventually, he did drink again, but not to the extent he had earlier in his life. He died of an [[aneurysm]] in 2004.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TE-vR-bHI7Q|title=WTF with Marc Maron Podcast Episode 477 Kevin Macdonald / Kevin McDonald|first=|last=Freddie Hodges|date=19 October 2014|publisher=|via=YouTube}} Kevin McDonald would use his relationship with his father as the basis for a one-man show, "Hammy And The Kids", in which he said he had no happy ending to the story of his father;{{cite web|url=http://www.hipstercrite.com/2010/09/06/hammy-and-the-kids/|title=Hammy and the Kids|publisher=}} but, during his interview with [[Marc Maron]], he said after one performance of his one-man show, he was approached by a stranger who said that he had served his father as a bartender, and that his father mentioned how proud he was of his son, the famous comedian, which moved McDonald to tears "like the ending to a bad movie." McDonald briefly studied acting at a community college, where he was kicked out for being "a one-legged actor" (i.e. he could perform comedy, but not drama) by a dean who had a leg amputated, and was therefore a literal one-legged actor. However, [[William B. Davis]], who would later find fame in his portrayal of [[Cigarette Smoking Man]] on ''[[The X-Files]]'', was one of his professors, saw McDonald's potential and encouraged him to pursue [[improv comedy]] by giving him the number to [[The Second City]] in Toronto. During his youth, he had a weight problem. It wasn't until just prior to ''The Kids in the Hall'' in the late 1980s that he went from overweight to rather skinny. Several sketches and monologues allude to the issue, and a stockier McDonald can be seen in archival footage on ''The Kids in the Hall'' on [[DVD]] [[box sets]]. ==Career== McDonald founded [[The Kids in the Hall]] comedy troupe with his friend [[Dave Foley]]. They met in [[Toronto]] at the [[Second City Training Center]], and the two wrote and performed in sketches together more than any other pair in the group. In the troupe's TV show and stage shows, he portrays several popular recurring characters, such as the King of Empty Promises, Sir Simon Milligan, and Jerry Sizzler. A frequent running gag was that McDonald is the least popular member and always struggling not to get kicked out. When the troupe ended the five-season run of its [[List of The Kids in the Hall episodes|eponymous television series]] in 1994, the five members moved to a number of solo projects. McDonald has played roles in movies like ''[[Boy Meets Girl (1998 film)|Boy Meets Girl]]'', [[Agent Pleakley]] in the [[Lilo & Stitch (franchise)|''Lilo & Stitch'' franchise]], and [[Harry Potter]] in ''[[Epic Movie]]''. On [[television]], he has appeared on ''[[The Martin Short Show]]'', ''[[Ellen (TV series)|Ellen]]'' (as a radio personality), ''[[That '70s Show]]'' (as a confused young cleric, Pastor Dave), ''[[Seinfeld]]'', ''[[Friends (TV series)|Friends]]'', ''[[NewsRadio]]'' (on which Foley starred), ''[[MADtv]]'', ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'', and ''[[Corner Gas]]''. McDonald has also done voice work for various animated series, including ''[[Invader Zim]]'' (in which he did the voice for Almighty Tallest Purple), ''[[The Angry Beavers]]'', ''[[Catscratch]]'' (in which he voiced Waffle), and ''[[Clerks: The Animated Series]]''. He also played an [[imaginary friend]] named Ivan in the ''[[Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends]]'' episode ''Sight For Sore Eyes'', and appeared in the music video for "Roses" by [[OutKast]]. In 2006, McDonald hosted a [[CBC Television]] special, ''Sketch with Kevin McDonald'', featuring several of Canada's best-known sketch comedy troupes. The special received two nominations, for the performances by [[The Minnesota Wrecking Crew]] and by The Imponderables, for [[Canadian Comedy Award]] in the category Best Taped Live Performance, with The Minnesota Wrecking Crew winning the award. Since 2000, McDonald and the other members of The Kids in the Hall have reunited for [[The Kids in the Hall#End of the show and beyond|a number of tours and televised performances]]. The troupe played the 2007 [[Just for Laughs]] festival, where McDonald also performed his one-and-a half-man show ''Hammy and the Kids'' with [[Craig Northey]], based on his two [[dysfunctional family|dysfunctional]] families, his father ("Hammy") and The Kids in the Hall. ==Filmography== ===Film and television=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:LightSteelBlue; text-align:center;" !
