{{Infobox football biography | name = Jean Michaël Seri | image = Jean Seri.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Seri training with Nice, 2018 | fullname = Jean Michaël Seri<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/844127 |title=2018/19 Premier League squads confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=3 September 2018 |accessdate=4 September 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|07|19|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Grand-Béréby]], Ivory Coast | height = 1.68 m<ref>{{cite web|title=Player Profile|url=http://www.ogcnice.com/en/teams/pros/squad/player/436/seri|publisher=OGC Nice Official website|accessdate=26 January 2018}}</ref> | position = [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|Central midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] | clubnumber = 24 | youthyears1 = 2007–2010 | youthclubs1 = [[Africa Sports d'Abidjan]] | years1 = 2010–2013 | clubs1 = [[ASEC Mimosas]] | caps1 = 16 | goals1 = 1 | years2 = 2012–2013 | clubs2 = → [[F.C. Porto B|Porto B]] (loan) | caps2 = 19 | goals2 = 1 | years3 = 2013–2015 | clubs3 = [[F.C. Paços de Ferreira|Paços de Ferreira]] | caps3 = 54 | goals3 = 2 | years4 = 2015–2018 | clubs4 = [[OGC Nice|Nice]] | caps4 = 103 | goals4 = 12 | years5 = 2018– | clubs5 = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] | caps5 = 26 | goals5 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2011 | nationalteam1 = [[Ivory Coast national under-23 football team|Ivory Coast U-23]] | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2015– | nationalteam2 = [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]] | nationalcaps2 = 23 | nationalgoals2 = 2 | club-update = 21:21, 9 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 13:34, 18 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''Jean Michaël Seri''' (born 19 July 1991) is an Ivorian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|central midfielder]] for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and the [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivorian national team]].
==Club career== ===Early career in the Ivory Coast=== In his native Ivory Coast, the young Seri was nicknamed "Galla", because he tried to emulate the former [[AS Monaco|Monaco]] and [[Paris Saint-Germain]] midfielder [[Marcelo Gallardo]], whose technical skills he admired. Seri joined the Ivorian football academy that was opened in 2001 by the Ivorian footballer [[Cyril Domoraud]]. "Jean is gifted, intelligent and respectful," Domoraud said in retrospect. "In his young days, he was one step ahead of the others, thanks to his ball control."<ref name="JeanSeriESPN5AUg2017">{{cite news|title=Arsenal target Jean Seri destined for big move after Nice displays|url=http://www.espnfc.com/english-premier-league/23/blog/post/3172560/arsenal-target-jean-seri-in-line-for-big-move-after-nice-displays|work=ESPN|date=5 August 2017}}</ref>
Born in the south-western city of [[Grand-Béréby]], Seri began his career as a youth player with [[Abidjan]] club [[Africa Sports d'Abidjan]] in July 2007.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jean-Michaël Seri at FootballDatabase.eu|url=http://www.footballdatabase.eu/football.joueurs.jean-michael.seri.134057.fr.html|work=FootballDatabase.eu}}</ref> The best clubs in Ivory Coast fought for his services. In January 2010, Seri started his career as a senior player by joining [[ASEC Mimosas]], the most successful club in Ivorian football, where he needed just one season to prove himself and become one of the best players in the country. "He is a great listener, and his state of mind is impeccable," raved Sébastien Desabre, ASEC Mimosas's head coach from October 2010 to October 2012 when Seri was a senior player there, and that quality enabled Seri to make steady progress.<ref name="JeanSeriESPN5AUg2017"/>
===Porto=== On 2 November 2012, Seri joined [[Primeira Liga]] club [[FC Porto]] on loan, after impressing their scouts. However, there was no place for Seri in the club's first team. He was thus forced to play for the club's [[FC Porto B|reserve team]], scoring once in 19 [[2012–13 Segunda Liga|Segunda Liga]] matches in the first five months of 2013.<ref name="JeanSeriESPN5AUg2017"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.record.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/liga-nos/fc-porto/detalhe/dragoes-garantem-jean-michael-seri-786352.html|title=Dragões garantem Jean-Michael Seri|trans-title=Dragons guarantee Jean-Michael Seri|work=[[Record (newspaper)|Record]]|date=2 November 2012|accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref><ref name="JeanSeri at Soccerway">{{cite news|title=Jean Seri at Soccerway|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/jean-michael-seri/171726/|work=Soccerway}}</ref>
===Paços de Ferreira=== On 31 August 2013, two months after finishing his loan spell at Porto (the ''Dragões''), Seri joined another [[Primeira Liga]] club [[F.C. Paços de Ferreira|Paços de Ferreira]] on a permanent basis and on a free transfer by signing a three-year deal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/fc-porto-jean-michel-seri-assina-pelo-p-ferreira/5221d1f984ae24c6a09fc476.html|title=FC Porto: Jean Michel Seri assina pelo P. Ferreira|trans-title=FC Porto: Jean Michel Seri signs for P. Ferreira|work=MaisFutebol|date=31 August 2013|accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref> He debuted for the ''Pacenses'' on 14 September 2013 against [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] in a [[2013–14 Primeira Liga|Primeira Liga]] 3–1 away loss.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.zerozero.pt/jogo.php?id=2838079|title=Benfica 3–1 P. Ferreira|trans-title=|work=ZeroZero|date=14 September 2013|accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref> On 2 March 2014, he scored a goal in the 54th minute to register his first competitive goal for Paços de Ferreira in a 3–1 Primeira Liga home win over [[C.S. Marítimo|Marítimo]] to send his side away from the relegation zone.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.zerozero.pt/jogo.php?id=2838213|title=P. Ferreira 3–1 Marítimo|trans-title=|work=ZeroZero|date=2 March 2014|accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref> It was at Paços de Ferreira where Seri's magnificent range of passing and ability to dictate the tempo of the game made him a fans' favourite. The club finished in eighth place in the [[2014–15 Primeira Liga]], and [[Ligue 1]] club [[OGC Nice|Nice]] were quick to sign Seri before bigger clubs took notice.<ref name="JeanSeriESPN5AUg2017"/>
===Nice=== On 11 June 2015, Seri officially joined [[Ligue 1]] club [[OGC Nice|Nice]] for a transfer fee of €1 million.<ref name="JeanSeriESPN5AUg2017"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Seri à Nice, c'est officiel|trans-title=Seri to Nice, it's official|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Seri-a-nice-c-est-officiel/565777|accessdate=19 February 2017|work=L'Equipe|date=11 June 2015|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Jean-Michaël Seri : L’Ivoirien signe à Nice|trans-title=Jean-Michaël Seri: The Ivorian signs to Nice|url=http://www.africatopsports.com/2015/06/11/jean-michael-seri-livoirien-signe-a-nice/|website=Africa Top Sports|accessdate=19 February 2017|language=French|date=11 June 2015}}</ref> On 27 May 2015, prior to the opening of the transfer window, the club had announced the "very likely" arrival of Seri.<ref>{{cite news|title=P. Ferreira: Nice confirma contratação de Seri|trans-title=P. Ferreira: Nice confirms Seri signing|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/transferencias/pacos-ferreira/p-ferreira-nice-confirma-contratacao-de-seri|accessdate=19 February 2017|work=MaisFutebol|date=27 May 2015|language=Portuguese}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Jean-Michael Seri arrive aussi|trans-title=Jean-Michael Seri also arrives|url=http://www.ogcnice.com/fr/actualite/23944/jean-michael-seri-arrive-aussi|website=OGC Nice|accessdate=19 February 2017|language=French}}</ref> On 8 August 2015, Seri made his competitive debut for Nice in their opening match of the [[2015–16 Ligue 1]] season, playing the entire match in the 2–1 home loss to [[AS Monaco|Monaco]]. On 27 September 2015, he scored in the 53rd minute to register his first competitive goal for Nice in a 4–1 Ligue 1 away win over [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]].<ref name="JeanSeri at Soccerway"/>
===Fulham=== In July 2018, Seri joined [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on a four-year deal until 2022 with an option for Fulham to extend the contract by a further year.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jean Michael Seri: Fulham sign Ivory Coast international from Nice |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44807027 |accessdate=12 July 2018 |work=BBC Sport |date=12 July 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Seri made a total of three appearances for the [[Ivory Coast national under-23 football team|Ivory Coast U-23 team]], all of them at the [[2011 CAF U-23 Championship]] held in Morocco, playing every minute of all their three Group B matches against South Africa, Egypt and Gabon. Ivory Coast finished third in Group B and thus did not qualify for the semifinals.
On 27 February 2014, Seri received his first senior international call up for the [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]] in an upcoming [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] against [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]];<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Nacional/1a_liga/pacos_ferreira/interior.aspx?content_id=870292 |title=Séri convocado para a seleção costa-marfinense |trans-title=Séri selected for the Ivorians |work=[[Record (newspaper)|Record]] |date=27 February 2014 |accessdate=11 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140305182620/http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Nacional/1a_liga/pacos_ferreira/interior.aspx?content_id=870292 |archivedate= 5 March 2014 |df= }}</ref> he was an unused substitute in ''The Elephants''' 2–2 away draw (held on 5 March 2014) against Belgium.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.kansascity.com/2014/03/05/4867900/belgium-draws-with-ivory-coast.html|title=Belgium draws with Ivory Coast 2–2 in WCup warm-up|trans-title=|work=KansasCitySports|date=5 March 2014|accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref> On 6 September 2015, Seri made his senior international debut in a [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualification Group I|2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualification match]] against [[Sierra Leone national football team|Sierra Leone]], playing the entire match in the 0–0 away draw. Seri played two of Ivory Coast's three [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations]] Group C matches. They finished third in Group C and thus did not qualify for the quarterfinals. On 17 November 2015, Seri scored a goal in the 64th minute of the [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – CAF Second Round|2018 FIFA World Cup qualification]] second round second leg 3–0 home win over [[Liberia national football team|Liberia]] to register his first senior international goal.

{{Spanish name|Rico|González}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Sergio Rico | image = Sergio Rico.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Rico with [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] in 2017 | fullname = Sergio Rico González{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/844127|title=2018/19 Premier League squads confirmed|publisher=Premier League|date=3 September 2018|accessdate=4 September 2018}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1993|9|1|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Seville]], Spain | height = 1.94 m{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/7213/Sergio-Rico/overview|title=Sergio Rico: Overview|publisher=Premier League|accessdate=15 October 2018}} | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | currentclub = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]
(on loan from [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]]) | clubnumber = 25 | youthyears1 = 2006–2011 | youthclubs1 = [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] | years1 = 2011–2014 | clubs1 = [[Sevilla Atlético|Sevilla B]] | caps1 = 36 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2014– | clubs2 = [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] | caps2 = 114 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2018– | clubs3 = → [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] (loan) | caps3 = 18 | goals3 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2016– | nationalteam1 = [[Spain national football team|Spain]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 09:04, 25 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 1 June 2016 }} '''Sergio Rico González''' ({{IPA-es|ˈseɾxjo ˈriko ɣonˈθaleθ}};{{efn-ua|In isolation, ''González'' is pronounced {{IPA-es|gonˈθaleθ|}}.}} born 1 September 1993) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for English club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on loan from [[Sevilla FC]] as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]]. He began his career at Sevilla, where he twice won the [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]]. Rico made his senior international debut for [[Spain national football team|Spain]] in 2016, and was chosen for [[UEFA Euro 2016|the year's European Championship]]. ==Club career== Rico was born in [[Seville]], [[Andalusia]]. He played youth football with [[Sevilla FC]], spending several of his first seasons as a senior with [[Sevilla Atlético|the reserves]], in [[Segunda División B]]. On 1 July 2013, he signed a new two-year deal with the club.{{cite news|url=http://sevilla.abc.es/deportes/orgullodenervion/noticias/sevilla-fc/sergio-rico-renueva-contrato-hara-pretemporada-primer-equipo-sevilla.html|title=Sergio Rico renueva dos años y hará la pretemporada con el primer equipo|trans-title=Sergio Rico renews for two years and will make the pre-season with the first team|newspaper=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]|last=Parejo|first=Jaime|language=es|date=1 July 2013|accessdate=15 September 2014}} On 14 September 2014, profiting from the injuries of both [[Beto (footballer, born 1982)|Beto]] and [[Mariano Barbosa]],{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=2141413.html|title=Beto, Barbosa present Sevilla with keeping crisis|publisher=UEFA|date=2 September 2014|accessdate=29 March 2015}} Rico made his first-team – and [[La Liga]] – debut, starting in a 2–0 home win against [[Getafe CF]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/spanish-primera-divisi%C3%B3n/match/402605/sevilla-fc-getafe/report|title=Sevilla FC 2–0 Getafe|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=14 September 2014|accessdate=15 September 2014}} He first appeared in the [[UEFA Europa League]] four days later, playing the full 90 minutes in a home success over [[Feyenoord]] for [[2014–15 UEFA Europa League|the same scoreline]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2015/matches/round=2000587/match=2014444/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Quick-fire Sevilla catch Feyenoord cold|publisher=UEFA|date=18 September 2014|accessdate=29 March 2015}} In December 2014, Rico was definitely promoted to the main squad, overtaking Barbosa in the pecking order.{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2014/12/03/futbol/equipos/sevilla/1417600813.html|title=Sergio Rico sí se queda|trans-title=Sergio Rico does remain|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|last=Quintero|first=Fede|language=es|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=29 March 2015}} He extended his contract with the ''Rojiblancos'' on the 16th, signing until 2017 and being awarded a place with the first team in the following campaign.{{cite news|url=http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2014/12/16/primera/1418761563_417689.html|title=Sergio Rico renueva hasta 2017|trans-title=Sergio Rico renews until 2017|newspaper=[[Diario AS]]|last=López|first=José María|language=es|date=16 December 2014|accessdate=29 March 2015}} He finished [[2014–15 La Liga|the campaign]] with 37 appearances all competitions comprised, including 11 in the Europa League{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2015/05/26/futbol/equipos/sevilla/1432631495.html|title=Consejo de héroes|trans-title=Council of heroes|newspaper=Marca|last=Fernández|first=Alberto|language=es|date=26 May 2015|accessdate=27 May 2015}} which concluded with a 3–2 win over [[FC Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk]] in [[2015 UEFA Europa League Final|the final]].{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3099823/Dnipro-2-3-Sevilla-Carlos-Bacca-scores-twice-La-Liga-survive-scare-retain-Europa-League-crown-earn-Champions-League-spot-dramatic-win-Warsaw.html|title=Dnipro 2–3 Sevilla: Carlos Bacca scores twice as La Liga side survive scare to retain Europa League crown and earn Champions League spot with dramatic win in Warsaw|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|last=Keegan|first=Mike|date=27 May 2015|accessdate=27 May 2015}} In [[2015–16 La Liga|2015–16]], Rico played in Sevilla's [[UEFA Champions League]] [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League|group stage elimination]], but was replaced by fellow youth graduate [[David Soria]] as the team [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League|went on to win]] a third consecutive Europa League title.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000663/match=2017222/postmatch/report/index.html#sevilla+make+three+liverpools+expense|title=Sevilla make it three in row at Liverpool's expense|publisher=UEFA|date=18 May 2016|accessdate=18 May 2016}} He was still first-choice during [[2017–18 La Liga|2017–18]], but was also involved in altercations with manager [[Vincenzo Montella]] and a group of supporters.{{cite news|url=https://www.elconfidencial.com/deportes/futbol/2018-04-07/sergio-rico-sevilla-montella-aficion-fallos_1545414/|title=Sergio Rico y su insostenible situación en el Sevilla por el pulgar abajo de la afición|trans-title=Sergio Rico and his unsustainable situation at Sevilla for the supporters thumbs down|newspaper=[[El Confidencial]]|last=Sánchez-Flor|first=Ulises|language=es|date=7 April 2018|access-date=9 August 2018}} On 9 August 2018, Rico was loaned to [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] for [[2018–19 Premier League|one season]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sevillafc.es/actualidad/noticias/sergio-rico-se-marcha-cedido-al-fulham-fc|title=Sergio Rico se marcha cedido al Fulham FC|trans-title=Sergio Rico goes out on loan at Fulham FC|publisher=Sevilla FC|language=es|date=9 August 2018|access-date=9 August 2018}} He made his [[Premier League]] debut on 27 October, in a 0–3 home loss against [[AFC Bournemouth]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45924057|title=Fulham 0–3 AFC Bournemouth|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|last=Holland|first=Kris|date=27 October 2018|accessdate=27 October 2018}} ==International career== On 26 May 2015, Rico and Sevilla teammate [[Aleix Vidal]] were the two players called up to the [[Spain national football team|Spanish national team]] for the first time, ahead of a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] with [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]] and a [[UEFA Euro 2016]] [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying|qualifying match]] against [[Belarus national football team|Belarus]],{{cite web|url=http://www.beinsports.tv/soccer/article/8fmekfgmj7141sxmbdb6mijvl/title/sevilla-duo-sergio-rico-and-aleix-vidal-handed-spain-calls|title=Sevilla duo Sergio Rico and Aleix Vidal handed Spain calls|publisher=[[beIN Sports]]|date=26 May 2015|accessdate=26 May 2015}} but he did not play in either fixture. He was the third-choice goalkeeper for the final tournament behind [[Iker Casillas]] and [[David de Gea]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36312769|title=Euro 2016: Diego Costa, Juan Mata & Fernando Torres not in Spain squad|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 May 2016|accessdate=17 May 2016}} and made his debut on 1 June, [[Substitute (association football)|replacing]] the former for the final 14 minutes of a 6–1 friendly win over [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]] in [[Salzburg]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/video-spain-6-1-south-korea-highlights-salzburg-friendly-ahead-euro-2016-2376728|title=VIDEO Spain 6–1 South Korea: Highlights from Salzburg friendly ahead of Euro 2016|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|last=Le Miere|first=Jason|date=1 June 2016|accessdate=1 June 2016}} ==Personal life== In December 2016, Rico was given the Sport award at the Young Andalusia Prizes, receiving his honour from regional president [[Susana Díaz]], a fan of [[Seville derby|city rivals]] [[Real Betis]].{{cite news|url=http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2016/12/21/primera/1482322835_729608.html|title=Susana Díaz: 'No hay bética que premie tanto a los sevillistas'|trans-title=Susana Díaz: 'There's no Betis fan who bestows so much awards on Sevilla players|newspaper=Diario AS|last=López|first=José María|language=es|date=21 December 2016|accessdate=24 December 2016}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== December 2018 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Alfie Robert John Mawson''' (born 19 January 1994) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[centre back]] for {{English football updater|Fulham}} club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].
He started his senior career with [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] from the youth ranks but spent his entire time on loan with four different clubs, including three separate loan spells with [[Maidenhead United F.C.|Maidenhead United]] and winning the [[EFL League Two|League Two]] Player of the Year award with [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]] in 2015. He was transferred to [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] after failing to record a League appearance with Brentford, and made 49 appearances during the one season there, helping the former to win promotion to the Championship. He signed for [[Premier League]] club [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] in 2016, and his second season there he featured in every Premier League match of the campaign but could not prevent the team from relegation.
Mawson has made six appearances for the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21 team]] and was called up for the [[England national football team|England]] squad in March 2018 but did not play in the two friendlies.
==Early life== Mawson was born and raised in [[Hillingdon]], London.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://origin-www.football-league.co.uk/championship/news/20160826/alfie-mawson-set-for-swansea-move-after-fee-agreed-with-barnsley_2293322_5840148 |title=Alfie Mawson set for Swansea move after fee agreed with Barnsley |publisher=The Football League |date=26 August 2016 |accessdate=24 March 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323213436/http://origin-www.football-league.co.uk/championship/news/20160826/alfie-mawson-set-for-swansea-move-after-fee-agreed-with-barnsley_2293322_5840148 |archive-date=23 March 2018 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/feb/10/swansea-alfie-mawson-chelsea-ball-dog |title=Alfie Mawson: 'I've got a football signed by Ranieri and the Chelsea players ... but my dog chewed it' |first=Stuart |last=James |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=10 February 2017 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Early career=== A [[centre back]], Mawson joined the [[Reading F.C. Under-23s and Academy|Reading academy]] at the age of nine.<ref name=chance>{{cite web |url=http://world.brentfordfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~2788675,00.html |title=Alfie looking to take his chance |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=11 July 2012 |accessdate=24 March 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323224649/http://world.brentfordfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~2788675,00.html |archive-date=23 March 2018 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He remained with the club until his release at age 15 and subsequently had unsuccessful trials with [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] and [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]].<ref name=chance/>
===Brentford=== Mawson joined [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in the summer of 2010 on a two-year scholarship.<ref name=footballconference>{{Cite web |url=http://footballconference.co.uk/news/details.php?news_id=9105 |title=Mawson returns to Maidenhead |date=21 February 2013 |publisher=Football Conference |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007031331/http://footballconference.co.uk/news/details.php?news_id=9105 |archivedate=7 October 2013 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> He played for the [[Brentford F.C. Reserves and Academy#Youth Team|youth team]] during the [[2010–11 Brentford F.C. season|2010–11 season]] and progressed into the [[Brentford F.C. Reserves and Academy#Development Squad|Development Squad]] during the [[2011–12 Brentford F.C. season|2011–12 season]],<ref name=chance/> making nine appearances.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://world.brentfordfc.co.uk/page/DevelopmentSquad/0,,10421~2455685,00.html |title=Development squad appearances |publisher=Brentford F.C. |accessdate=24 March 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323231920/http://world.brentfordfc.co.uk/page/DevelopmentSquad/0,,10421~2455685,00.html |archive-date=23 March 2018 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He also took over the youth team [[Captain (association football)|captaincy]] during the latter part of the season.<ref name=Contracts>{{Cite web |url=http://world.brentfordfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~2724983,00.html |title=Development squad contracts |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=24 March 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323232059/http://world.brentfordfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~2724983,00.html |archive-date=23 March 2018 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In April 2012, Mawson signed a two-year professional contract at Brentford.<ref name=Contracts/> He was included in the squad for the Bees' [[pre-season]] tour of Germany in July 2012 and appeared in the opening match against [[ZFC Meuselwitz]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2012/july/zfc-meuselwitz-1-brentford-1/ |title=ZFC Meuselwitz 1 Brentford 1 |first=Mark |last=Chapman |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=21 July 2012 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> Mawson suffered an injury-hit [[2012–13 Brentford F.C. season|2012–13 season]] and managed only 12 Development Squad appearances.<ref name=Maidenhead>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2013/october/mawson-returns-to-maidenhead/ |title=Mawson returns to Maidenhead |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=4 October 2013 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref>
Mawson made his professional debut in a 5–0 [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] second round defeat at [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] in August 2013, replacing [[Sam Saunders (footballer)|Sam Saunders]] after 73 minutes.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/23764109 |title=Derby 5–0 Brentford |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 August 2013 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He scored his first goal of the [[2013–14 Brentford F.C. season|2013–14]] season with the opener in a 1–1 [[Professional Development League|Professional Development League 2 South]] draw with [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] on 16 September 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2013/september/brighton-ds-1-brentford-ds-1/ |title=Brighton DS 1 Bretnford DS 1 |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=16 September 2013 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He scored his second goal in a 4–1 defeat to [[Ipswich Town F.C. Youth Academy|Ipswich Town]] on 26 November and his third in the return fixture against Brighton & Hove Albion on 27 January 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2013/november/brentford-ds-1-ipswich-town-ds-4/ |title=Brentford DS 1 Ipswich Town DS 4 |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=26 November 2013 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/january/brentford-ds-2-brighton-ds-1/ |title=Brentford DS 2 Brighton DS 1 |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=27 January 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> Mawson made 12 appearances and scored three goals for the Development Squad during the 2013–14 season,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/may/201314-development-squad-stats/ |title=2013/14 Development squad stats |first=Ciaran |last=Brett |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=31 May 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> in addition to making one first-team appearance.<ref name=sb1314/> A torn [[Meniscus (anatomy)|meniscus]] in a Development Squad match ended Mawson's season early, prompting him to contemplate quitting football,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/brentford-defender-quit-football---9276027 |title=Brentford defender almost quit football – now he's preparing for dream Wembley showdown with Wycombe |first=Matt |last=Lewis |website=Get West London |publisher=Trinity Mirror Southern |date=18 May 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> before signing a new one-year deal on 5 June 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/june/alfie-mawson-signs-new-contract/ |title=Alfie Mawson signs new contract |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=5 June 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> Mawson spent the entire [[2014–15 Brentford F.C. season|2014–15 season]] away on loan and after excelling, he was offered a new two-year contract in April 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2015/april/three-young-players-offered-new-brentford-contracts/ |title=Three young players offered new Brentford contracts |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=30 April 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He turned the deal down and departed [[Griffin Park]] when his contract expired on 30 June.<ref name=BBC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/33330254 |title=Alfie Mawson: Barnsley sign former Brentford defender |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 June 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> An undisclosed compensation fee was agreed in February 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2016/february/compensation-agreement-finalised-for-alfie-mawson/ |title=Compensation agreement finalised for Alfie Mawson |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=23 February 2016 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref>
====Maidenhead United (loans)==== Mawson signed for [[National League South|Conference South]] club [[Maidenhead United F.C.|Maidenhead United]] on 13 December 2012 on a one-month loan,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2012/december/mawson-joins-maidenhead-on-loan/ |title=Mawson joins Maidenhead on loan |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=13 December 2012 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> earning praise from manager [[Johnson Hippolyte]] for his performance on his debut in a 1–0 win against [[Truro City F.C.|Truro City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sloughexpress.co.uk/Sport/Football/Maidenhead-Utd-FC/New-defensive-duo-impress-Maidenhead-United-FC-boss-19122012.htm |title=New defensive duo impress Maidenhead United FC boss |first=Charles |last=Watts |newspaper=Slough & South Bucks Express |date=20 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303222645/http://www.sloughexpress.co.uk/Sport/Football/Maidenhead-Utd-FC/New-defensive-duo-impress-Maidenhead-United-FC-boss-19122012.htm |archivedate=3 March 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Mawson returned to Brentford on 9 January 2013,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maidenhead-advertiser.co.uk/Sport/Football/Maidenhead-Utd-FC/Mawson-returns-to-Brentford-after-Maidenhead-United-loan-spell-10012013.htm |title=Mawson returns to Brentford after Maidenhead United loan spell |first=Charles |last=Watts |newspaper=Maidenhead Advertiser |date=10 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305010903/http://www.maidenhead-advertiser.co.uk/Sport/Football/Maidenhead-Utd-FC/Mawson-returns-to-Brentford-after-Maidenhead-United-loan-spell-10012013.htm |archivedate=5 March 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> before re-signing for Maidenhead United on loan for the rest of the season on 21 February.<ref name=footballconference/> He made nine appearances during the [[2012–13 Football Conference#Conference South|2012–13 season]] as Maidenhead narrowly avoided relegation.<ref name=Soccerway/> Mawson rejoined Maidenhead United for a third loan spell on 4 October 2013, which ran initially until 29 October and was later extended until 4 January 2014.<ref name=Maidenhead/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2013/october/mawson-to-stay-at-maidenhead/ |title=Mawson to stay at Maidenhead |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=30 October 2013 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> Mawson was recalled from his loan early on 28 November after four appearances.<ref name=BrentfordFC>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2013/november/mawson-moves-to-luton-on-loan/ |title=Mawson moves to Luton on loan |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=28 November 2013 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref>
====Luton Town (loan)==== On 28 November 2013, Mawson moved on loan to [[National League (division)|Conference Premier]] club [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] until 4 January 2014, to cover for injuries to [[Defender (association football)|defenders]] [[Steve McNulty]], [[Andy Parry]], [[Alex Lacey]] and [[Anthony Charles]].<ref name=BrentfordFC/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.lutontown.co.uk/news/2013/november/hatters-loan-defensive-trio/ |title=Hatters loan defensive trio |publisher=Luton Town F.C. |date=28 November 2013 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He made his debut in a 5–0 away league victory over [[Alfreton Town F.C.|Alfreton Town]] on 7 December, but was substituted for [[Joe Davis (footballer, born 1993)|Joe Davis]] at half time due to an injury.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25164371 |title=Alfreton Town 0–5 Luton Town |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 December 2013 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He returned to Brentford on 10 January after making just one appearance.<ref name=Soccerway/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/january/alfie-mawsons-luton-loan-ends/ |title=Alfie Mawson'S Luton loan ends |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=10 January 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref>
====Welling United (loan)==== On 31 January 2014, Mawson joined Conference Premier club [[Welling United F.C.|Welling United]] on loan until the end of the [[2013–14 Football Conference#Conference Premier|2013–14 season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/january/alfie-mawson-joins-welling-united/ |title=Alfie Mawson joins Welling United |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=31 January 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He made his debut with a start in a 1–1 draw away to [[Tamworth F.C.|Tamworth]] on 22 February.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/matches/2014/02/22/england/conference-national/tamworth-fc/welling-united-fc/1507680/ |title=Tamworth vs. Welling United 1–1 |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> Mawson scored his first Wings goal on his second appearance, heading home the second in a 2–0 home win over [[Gateshead F.C.|Gateshead]] on 25 February.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/26247261 |title=Welling United 2–0 Gateshead |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 February 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> A knee injury disrupted Mawson's time at Welling and he returned to Brentford at the end of the season, having made 9 appearances and scored one goal.<ref name=sb1314/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/may/academy-players-return-after-loans-end/ |title=Academy players return after loans end |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=1 May 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref>
====Wycombe Wanderers (loan)==== Mawson joined [[EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]] on 9 August 2014 on a one-month youth loan, as cover for the injured [[Gary Doherty]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/august/alfie-mawson-joins-wycombe-on-loan/ |title=Alfie Mawson joins Wycombe on loan |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=9 August 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He made his Wycombe debut (the first [[English Football League|Football League]] appearance of his career) on the opening day of the [[2014–15 Wycombe Wanderers F.C. season|2014–15]] season, playing the full 90 minutes of a 2–0 away win over [[Newport County A.F.C.|Newport County]] alongside former Brentford teammate [[Aaron Pierre]] at centre back.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28646857 |title=Newport County 0–2 Wycombe Wanderers |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 August 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wycombe.vitalfootball.co.uk/article.asp?a=366027 |title=Blues off to a flier in Wales |first=Adam |last=Clift |website=Vital Wycombe |date=9 August 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> After appearing in each of Wycombe's first six matches of the season, Mawson's loan was extended until 1 January 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/september/alfie-mawson-extends-wycome-loan/ |title=Alfie Mawson extends Wycombe loan |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=1 September 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> Mawson's 100% appearance record came to an end on his 19th appearance of the season, after suffering an injury in a 3–1 defeat to [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] on 17 November.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/november/loan-round-up8/ |title=Loan round up |first=Ciaran |last=Brett |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=24 November 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref><ref name=sb1415/> He returned to action on 29 November against [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] and capped Wycombe's afternoon with the first Football League goal of his career in a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30156386 |title=Hartlepool United 1–3 Wycombe Wanderers |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 November 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> His performance won him a place in the Football League Team of the Week.<ref name=FL>{{cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/news/2014/december/sky-bet-football-league-team-of-the-week/ |title=Sky Bet Football League Team of the Week |first=Ryan |last=Percival |publisher=The Football League |date=1 December 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref>
On 3 January 2015, Mawson's loan was extended until the end of the season, including the play-offs if required, with no recall clause.<ref name=Wycombe>{{cite web |url=https://www.wycombewanderers.co.uk/news/2015/january/alfie-mawson-to-stay-for-the-season/ |title=Alfie Mawson to stay for the season |publisher=Wycombe Wanderers F.C. |date=3 January 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> Mawson's three goals in four matches in March helped ensure Wycombe held onto the third automatic promotion place.<ref name=sb1415/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statto.com/football/teams/wycombe-wanderers/2014-2015/table/2015-03-24 |title=Wycombe Wanderers 2014–2015: Table: Table on Tuesday 24th March 2015 |publisher=Statto Organisation |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402115849/http://www.statto.com/football/teams/wycombe-wanderers/2014-2015/table/2015-03-24 |archivedate=2 April 2015 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> He scored a vital winning goal in Wycombe's 2–1 victory over [[Cheltenham Town F.C.|Cheltenham Town]] on 11 April,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32179955 |title=Wycombe Wanderers 2–1 Cheltenham Town |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 April 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> to end a run of successive defeats, which kept Wycombe four points clear of fourth-place [[Bury F.C.|Bury]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statto.com/football/teams/wycombe-wanderers/2014-2015/table/2015-04-11 |title=Wycombe Wanderers 2014–2015: Table: Table on Saturday 11th April 2015 |publisher=Statto Organisation |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208133926/http://www.statto.com/football/teams/wycombe-wanderers/2014-2015/table/2015-04-11 |archivedate=8 December 2015 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Mawson's performance was recognised with his second inclusion of the season in the Football League Team of the Week.<ref name=FootballLeague>{{cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/news/2015/april/sky-bet-football-league-team-of-the-week/ |title=Sky Bet Football League Team of the Week |first=Alex |last=Butcher |publisher=The Football League |date=13 April 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> Mawson's 97th-minute winner in a 3–2 victory over [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] on the final day was not enough to prevent Wycombe from having to settle for fourth place and a [[2015 Football League play-offs#League Two|play-off semi-final]] matchup versus [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32460232 |title=Northampton Town 2–3 Wycombe Wanderers |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 May 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statto.com/football/teams/wycombe-wanderers/2014-2015/table/2015-05-02 |title=Wycombe Wanderers 2014–2015: Table: Table on Saturday 2nd May 2015 |publisher=Statto Organisation |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150707174333/http://www.statto.com/football/teams/wycombe-wanderers/2014-2015/table/2015-05-02 |archivedate=7 July 2015 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> However, his season ended in disappointment after a penalty shoot-out defeat to Southend United in the [[2015 Football League Two play-off Final|final]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32762821 |title=Southend United 1–1 Wycombe Wanderers |first=Phil |last=Shepka |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 May 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He finished the 2014–15 season with 50 appearances and seven goals.<ref name=sb1415/> Mawson swept the board at Wycombe's end-of-season awards ceremony, winning the Supporters' and Players' Player of the Year awards, in addition to the Official Wycombe Wanderers Supporters Association's Player, Young Player and Away Travel Player of the Year awards.<ref name=SeasonAwards>{{cite news |url=http://www.bucksfreepress.co.uk/sport/12929717.Mawson_cleans_up_at_Wanderers__end_of_season_awards_night/ |title=Mawson cleans up at Wanderers' end of season awards night |first=Greg |last=Styles |newspaper=Bucks Free Press |date=4 May 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He also won the Wycombe Wanderers Independent Supporters' Club Player of the Year award.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2015/april/wycombe-supporters-award-for-alfie-mawson/ |title=Wycombe supporters' award for Alfie Mawson |first=Chris |last=Wickham |publisher=Brentford F.C. |date=27 April 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He finished third in the running for the League Two Player of the Year award.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12040/9814522/patrick-bamford-has-been-named-sky-bet-championship-player-of-the-year |title=Patrick Bamford named Sky Bet Championship Player of the Year |publisher=Sky Sports |date=20 April 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref>
===Barnsley=== Mawson signed for [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on 30 June 2015 on a three-year contract.<ref name=BBC/> He scored his first goal for the Reds in a 3–2 away win over Millwall.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/33857834 |title=Millwall 2–3 Barnsley |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 August 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He impressed in the [[2015–16 Barnsley F.C. season|2015–16 season]], scoring seven goals in 58 appearances.<ref name=sb1516/> He played a big part in Barnsley's season, including beating Oxford United 3–2 to win the [[Football League Trophy]] on 3 April 2016,<ref name=2016FLT>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35906363 |title=Barnsley 3–2 Oxford United |first=Phil |last=Cartwright |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 April 2016 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> and in earning promotion to the Championship after beating Millwall 3–1 in the play-off final.<ref name=2016PO>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36352352 |title=Barnsley 3–1 Millwall |first=Rob |last=Stevens |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 May 2016 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref>
===Swansea City=== [[File:Alfie Mawson 2017-11-29 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Mawson playing for [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] in 2017]]
After just four league matches experience in the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] with Barnsley, Mawson signed for [[Premier League]] club [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] on 30 August 2016 on a four-year contract<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37201308 |title=Alfie Mawson: Swansea City sign Barnsley defender |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 August 2016 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.swanseacity.com/news/alfie-mawson-aims-seize-swansea-city-chance-after-joining-barnsley |title=Alfie Mawson aims to seize Swansea City chance after joining from Barnsley |publisher=Swansea City A.F.C. |date=30 August 2016 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He made his full debut on 22 October 2016 in the 0–0 home draw against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37663772 |title=Swansea City 0–0 Watford |first=Dafydd |last=Pritchard |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 October 2016 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> in the Premier League after which he presented with the man of the match award for his work in defence.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.swansea.vitalfootball.co.uk/article.asp?a=465893 |title=Mawson wins man of the match on debut vs Watford |website=Vital Swansea |date=26 October 2016 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club on 3 January 2017 in a 2–1 win against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38441016 |title=Crystal Palace 1–2 Swansea City |first=Michael |last=Emons |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 January 2017 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref>
In the [[2017–18 Swansea City A.F.C. season|2017–18]] season, Mawson scored the only goal in a 1–0 home win against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 22 January 2018 to help Swansea's survival hopes.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42685212 |title=Swansea City 1–0 Liverpool |first=Michael |last=Pearlman |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 January 2018 |accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref> Despite this, the club struggled, particularly on the attacking point of view, and despite the player featured in all 38 Premier League fixtures, he did not prevent the club's relegation, which was confirmed on the final day of the season.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44020155 | title=Swansea 1–2 Stoke | publisher = BBC Sport | first = Dafydd | last = Pritchard | date=14 May 2018 | accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref><ref name=sb1718/>
===Fulham=== After Swansea's relegation from the Premier League, Mawson signed for newly promoted club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on a four-year contract for an undisclosed fee, reported to be in the region of £20 million.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45024377 |title=Alfie Mawson: Fulham sign defender from Swansea City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 August 2018 |accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2018/august/02/totally-mawson |title=Mawson signs |publisher=Fulham F.C. |date=2 August 2018 |accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Mawson played six times and scored one goal for the [[England national under-21 football team|England national under-21 team]] from 2016 to 2017, scoring his only goal on 19 June 2017 in a 2–1 win against [[Slovakia national under-21 football team|Slovakia]] at the [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslTmU21pg4.html |title=England's matches: The under 21's: 2010–20 |website=England Football Online |publisher=Chris Goodwin, Glen Isherwood & Peter Young |date=9 June 2018 |accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref> England were eventually knocked out by [[Germany national under-21 football team|Germany]] in the semi-final.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
On 15 March 2018, Mawson was named for the first time in the [[England national football team|England]] squad for pre-[[2018 FIFA World Cup]] friendlies against the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] and [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in March.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43344416 |title=England call-ups for uncapped quartet as Jack Wilshere earns recall |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 March 2018 |accessdate=15 March 2018}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Lazar Marković | image = Lazar Markovic in Bangkok (19714140242).jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Marković training with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in 2015 | fullname = Lazar Marković<ref>{{cite web|title=Premier League Clubs submit Squad Lists|url=http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/squad-lists/Premier-League-squad-lists-September-2014.pdf|publisher=Premier League|format=PDF|date=3 September 2014|page=21|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022192726/http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/squad-lists/Premier-League-squad-lists-September-2014.pdf|archivedate=22 October 2014}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1994|3|2|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Čačak]], [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|FR Yugoslavia]] | height = {{height|m=1.78}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/players/profile.overview.html/lazar-markovic|title=Premier League Player Profile Lazar Markovic|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date=2014|website=Premier League|publisher=Barclays Premier League|accessdate=7 January 2015}}</ref> | position = [[Winger (association football)|Winger]] | currentclub = [[Fulham F.C|Fulham]] | clubnumber = 30 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[FK Borac Čačak|Borac Čačak]] | youthyears2 = 2006–2011 | youthclubs2 = [[FK Partizan|Partizan]] | years1 = 2011–2013 | clubs1 = [[FK Partizan|Partizan]] | caps1 = 46 | goals1 = 13 | years2 = 2013–2014 | clubs2 = [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] | caps2 = 26 | goals2 = 5 | years3 = 2014–2019 | clubs3 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps3 = 19 | goals3 = 2 | years4 = 2015–2016 | clubs4 = → [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]] (loan) | caps4 = 14 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2016–2017 | clubs5 = → [[Sporting CP]] (loan) | caps5 = 6 | goals5 = 1 | years6 = 2017 | clubs6 = → [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] (loan) | caps6 = 12 | goals6= 2 | years7 = 2018 | clubs7 = → [[RSCA|Anderlecht]] (loan) | caps7 = 8 | goals7 = 1 | years8 = 2019– | clubs8 = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] | caps8 = 1 | goals8 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2009–2011 | nationalteam1 = [[Serbia national under-17 football team|Serbia U17]]<ref name=UEFA>Only official [[UEFA]] matches included</ref> | nationalcaps1 = 8 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2011–2016 | nationalteam2 = [[Serbia national under-21 football team|Serbia U21]]<ref name=UEFA/> | nationalcaps2 = 2 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2012– | nationalteam3 = [[Serbia national football team|Serbia]] | nationalcaps3 = 22 | nationalgoals3 = 3 | club-update = 20:50, 22 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 15 November 2016 }} '''Lazar Marković''' ({{lang-sr-Cyrl|Лазар Марковић}}, {{IPA-sh|lâzaːr mǎːrkoʋitɕ|pron}}; born 2 March 1994) is a Serbian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and the [[Serbia national football team|Serbia national team]].
He started his career at [[FK Partizan|Partizan]] before moving to [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] in 2013, where he won a domestic [[Treble (association football)|treble]] in his only season, after which he completed a £20 million move to Liverpool. His second season at Liverpool was spent on loan at [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]], and finished prematurely due to injury. He was then transferred to [[Sporting CP]] on a season-long loan, which was cancelled in January 2017, after which he was loaned to [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]]. In January 2019 he moved to [[Fulham F.C|Fulham]] on a free transfer after not making a competitive appearance for Liverpool since May 2015.
Marković made his full international debut for Serbia in 2012.
==Club career== ===Partizan=== After playing for the youth selections of [[FK Borac Čačak|Borac Čačak]], Marković joined [[FK Partizan|Partizan]] in 2006 as a 12-year-old trainee.<ref name=interview>{{cite news | url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/sport.294.html:352273-Braca-Markovic-Sanjamo-Ligu-sampiona | title=Braća Marković: Sanjamo Ligu šampiona! | language=Serbian | publisher=novosti.rs | date=7 November 2011 | accessdate=18 November 2011}}</ref> On 29 May 2011, coach [[Aleksandar Stanojević]] promoted Marković to the first team ahead of the final round of the [[2010–11 Serbian SuperLiga|2010–11 SuperLiga]], which Partizan played against [[FK Sloboda Užice|Sloboda Užice]]. He was given the number 50 shirt. Marković was used as a second-half substitute for [[Joseph Kizito]] in his team's 2–1 win.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/sport.72.html:332319-JSL-Partizan-pobedio-i-na-rastanku | title=JSL: Partizan pobedio i na rastanku | language=Serbian | publisher=novosti.rs | date=29 May 2011 | accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref>
====2011–12 season==== On 11 July 2011, together with [[Nikola Ninković]], Marković signed his first professional contract with Partizan, for five years.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.partizan.rs/14289-markovi%C4%87-i-ninkovi%C4%87-profesionalci/ | title=Marković i Ninković profesionalci! | language=Serbian | publisher=partizan.rs | date=11 July 2011 | accessdate=11 July 2011 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://sport.blic.rs/Fudbal/Domaci-fudbal/200111/Partizan-osvezio-vezni-red-svojim-talentima-Ninkovicem-i-Markovicem | title=Partizan osvežio vezni red svojim talentima, Ninkovićem i Markovićem | language=Serbian | publisher=blic.rs | date=11 July 2011 | accessdate=11 July 2011}}</ref> Marković made his first appearance of the 2011–12 season in Partizan's opener against [[KF Shkëndija|Shkëndija]], in the qualifying round of the [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]], playing the last three minutes of the match.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2012/matches/round=2000260/match=2007494/index.html | title=Four-goal Partizan too hot for Skendija | publisher=uefa.com | date=13 July 2011 | accessdate=18 April 2012}}</ref> He scored his first senior goal in a league match against [[FK Novi Pazar|Novi Pazar]], on 13 August 2011.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.mozzartsport.com/vesti/5181/presre%C4%87ni-markovi%C4%87/ | title=Presrećni Marković | language=Serbian | publisher=mozzartsport.com | date=15 August 2011 | accessdate=22 August 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325045514/http://www.mozzartsport.com/vesti/5181/presre%C4%87ni-markovi%C4%87/ | archivedate=25 March 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> At the end of 2011, Marković was voted Partizan's Player of the Year in a poll on the club's website.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.b92.net/sport/fudbal/vesti.php?yyyy=2011&mm=12&dd=24&nav_id=568504 | title=Marković najbolji igrač Partizana | language=Serbian | publisher=b92.net | date=24 December 2011 | accessdate=18 April 2012}}</ref> In his first full senior season, Marković made 26 league appearances and scored six goals. Despite not scoring a goal in the second half of the championship, Marković earned [[2011–12 Serbian SuperLiga|2011–12 SuperLiga]] Team of the Year selection.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://sport.blic.rs/Fudbal/Domaci-fudbal/214566/Lazovic-Markovic-i-Simic-predvode-idealan-tim-Superlige | title=Lazović, Marković i Šimić predvode idealan tim Superlige | language=Serbian | publisher=blic.rs | date=14 May 2012 | accessdate=4 June 2012}}</ref>
====2012–13 season==== As Partizan appeared in the [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League group stage|group stage of an UEFA competition]] for the first time since 2010, Marković appeared in all group fixtures, impressing against the likes of [[Neftçi PFK|Neftchi Baku]], [[FC Rubin Kazan|Rubin Kazan]] and [[Inter Milan|Internazionale]]. In the group stage, he assisted Saša Marković against Rubin Kazan on 6 December 2012. By the end of the 2012–13 season, Marković appeared in 19 league games and scored 7 goals and earned a place in the SuperLiga's Team of the Year selection for the second-straight season.<ref>[http://www.mozzartsport.com/vesti/idealnih-11-superlige-partizan-pet-vosa-tri-zvezda-hajduk-i-srem-po-jednog-predstavnika] Mozzart Sport (Serbian): Idealnih 11 Superlige: Partizan pet, Voša tri, Zvezda, Hajduk i Srem po jednog predstavnika! (VIDEO) – 27 May 2013</ref> Additionally, Serbian sports portal ''Mozzart Sport'' rated Marković among the 25 best players in the [[Serbian SuperLiga|SuperLiga]] that season.<ref>[http://www.mozzartsport.com/vesti/top-25-najboljih-fudbalera-superlige-u-izboru-mozzart-sporta-video] Mozzart Sport (Serbian): TOP 25 najboljih fudbalera Superlige u izboru MOZZART Sporta (VIDEO) – 2 June 2013</ref>
===Benfica=== On the morning hours of 10 June 2013, Partizan club president [[Dragan Đurić]] told ''[[Sportski žurnal]]'', "[[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] wants to loan Marković to [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] for two years, and honestly speaking, I hope to God that they don't come to an agreement so that Lazar can stay six more months at Partizan."<ref>{{cite web|script-title=sr:КРАЈ САГЕ: Челзи позајмио Марковића у Бенфику на две године|url=http://www.zurnal.rs/2013/06/10/kraj-sage-celzi-pozajmio-markovica-u-benfiku-na-dve-godine/index.html|work=zurnal.rs|language=Serbian|date=10 June 2013}}</ref> This statement was later misinterpreted by several non-Serbian sports news outlets, which incorrectly cited Đurić stating, "It is true, Chelsea will send Marković on a loan for two years."<ref>{{cite web|title=Partizan Belgrade Claim Chelsea Have Already Signed Serbian Youngster Lazar Markovic|url=http://www.caughtoffside.com/2013/06/10/partizan-belgrade-claim-chelsea-have-already-signed-croatian-youngster-lazar-markovic/|work=caughtoffside.com|date=10 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Partizan: Chelsea own Markovic|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/foxsoccer/premierleague/story/Partizan-Chelsea-own-Markovic-28825949|work=FOX Sports|date=10 June 2013}}</ref> Approximately eight hours after the article was published, Benfica's official website released a statement stating Marković had signed a five-year contract with the club, not mentioning any loan deal with Chelsea.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lazar Markovic contratado pelo SL Benfica por cinco temporadas|trans-title=Lazar Markovic signed by Benfica for five seasons|url=http://aovivo.slbenfica.pt/Noticias/DetalhedeNoticia/tabid/790/ArticleId/30008/language/pt-PT/Lazar-Markovic-contratado-pelo-SL-Benfica-por-cinco-temporadas.aspx|work=S.L. Benfica|language=Portuguese|date=10 June 2013}}</ref> The earlier statements regarding a potential loan deal with Chelsea caused great confusion among journalists and followers of the transfer saga alike.<ref>{{cite web|title=Benfica contradict Partizan, claim they're signed Markovic to 5-year deal|url=http://www.weaintgotnohistory.com/chelsea-fc-transfer-rumours-news/2013/6/10/4415428/lazar-markovic-transfer-rumour-benfica|work=weaintgotnohistory.com|date=10 June 2013}}</ref>
On 25 August 2013, Marković made his debut for Benfica in 2–1 win against [[Gil Vicente F.C.|Gil Vicente]], scoring a decisive goal at the 92nd minute that drew the game.<ref>{{cite web|title=Benfica 2–1 Gil Vicente|url=http://espnfc.com/uk/en/gamecast/statistics/id/372753/statistics.html?soccernet=true&cc=5739|work=espnfc.com|date=25 August 2013}}</ref> On the third matchday of the [[2013–14 Primeira Liga]] season, against [[Sporting CP]] at the [[Estádio José Alvalade]], Marković scored the equalizing goal after a dribble past three players, as the match ended in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite web|title=SuperLiga – New signings shine as Lisbon derby ends in draw |url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/superliga-sporting-lisbon-v-benfica-live-185345122.html |work=uk.eurosport.yahoo.com |date=31 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130904090640/http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/superliga-sporting-lisbon-v-benfica-live-185345122.html |archivedate= 4 September 2013 |df= }}</ref> On 1 May 2014, in injury time of Benfica's [[2013–14 UEFA Europa League]] [[2013–14 UEFA Europa League knockout phase#Semi-finals|semi-final second leg match]] against [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], Marković was sent off for a fight with his opponent [[Mirko Vučinić]]. Neither were on the field of play at the time, Marković having been substituted and Vučinić still on the substitutes' bench. Marković therefore missed [[2014 UEFA Europa League Final|the final]] through suspension; Benfica lost the final to [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] on penalties (4–2) after a 0–0 draw.<ref>{{cite news|title=Juventus 0–0 Benfica|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27226534|accessdate=2 May 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=1 May 2014}}</ref>
===Liverpool=== ====2014–15 season==== [[File:Lazar Markovic 2014.jpg|thumb|upright|Marković with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in 2014]]
On 15 July 2014, [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] announced the signing of Marković from Benfica for £20 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=Reds complete Markovic deal|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/166355-reds-complete-markovic-deal|work=[[Liverpool F.C.]]|accessdate=15 July 2014|date=15 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28188589|title= Liverpool complete £20m signing of Lazar Markovic|date=16 July 2014|work=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=16 July 2014}}</ref> Benfica received €12.5 million for their 50% share of his economic rights.<ref>{{cite web|title=Comunicado|url=http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi2004/emitentes/docs/FR51293.pdf|publisher=[[CMVM]]|accessdate=15 July 2014|language=Portuguese|date=15 July 2014}}</ref> He made his competitive debut on 25 August in Liverpool's second match of the [[2014–15 Premier League|2014–15]] [[Premier League]] season, replacing [[Philippe Coutinho]] after 60 minutes of a 3–1 defeat at [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|title=Man City 3–1 Liverpool|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28831352|accessdate=17 September 2014|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=25 August 2014}}</ref> In Liverpool's final group stage match in the [[2014–15 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]], on 9 December 2014 against [[FC Basel|Basel]], Marković was shown a straight red card for [[Fouls and misconduct (association football)#Red card (dismissal)|violent conduct]] after he appeared to flick his fingers into the face of opponent [[Behrang Safari]]. The match ended in a 1–1 draw, which saw Liverpool drop into the [[2014–15 UEFA Europa League|UEFA Europa League]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2867769/Lazar-Markovic-deserved-sent-referee-right-turn-Steven-Gerrard-penalty-appeal.html|title=Lazar Markovic deserved to be sent off for Liverpool and referee was right to turn down Steven Gerrard penalty appeal|date=10 December 2014|work=[[Mail Online]]|accessdate=10 December 2014}}</ref> In February 2015, Marković was given a four-match European ban for this incident.<ref>{{cite news|title=Liverpool's Lazar Markovic handed four-game European ban|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31506569|accessdate=17 February 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=17 February 2015}}</ref>
Marković scored his first goal for Liverpool against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] in the [[2014–15 Football League Cup|League Cup]] quarter-finals on 17 December 2014, scoring in the 27th minute of a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/dec/17/bournemouth-liverpool-capital-one-cup-quarter-final|title= Raheem Sterling double helps Liverpool recover poise against Bournemouth|date=17 December 2014|work=Guardian|accessdate=19 December 2014}}</ref> On 10 January 2015, he scored his first Premier League goal, netting in the eight minute for the only goal in a victory at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]]'s [[Stadium of Light]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Sunderland 0–1 Liverpool|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30663770|accessdate=10 January 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=10 January 2015}}</ref> On 10 February, he opened the scoring for Liverpool in a 3–2 win over [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], his first Premier League goal at [[Anfield]].
====2015–16: Loan to Fenerbahçe==== On 30 August 2015, Marković joined [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]] on a season-long loan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/192925-markovic-completes-fenerbahce-loan-switch|title=Markovic completes Fenerbahce loan switch|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|accessdate=30 August 2015|date=30 August 2015}}</ref> He made his [[Süper Lig]] debut on 13 September, replacing [[Robin van Persie]] in the 62nd minute of a 1–0 win at [[Kasımpaşa S.K.|Kasımpaşa]], and scored his first goal on 10 December by opening a 1–1 draw against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] at the [[Şükrü Saracoğlu Stadium]]. The result advanced the ''Yellow Canaries'' to the last 32 of the [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Celtic level but Fenerbahçe forge on|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000658/match=2017043/index.html|accessdate=18 April 2016|publisher=UEFA|date=10 December 2015}}</ref>
On 21 January 2016, Marković scored his first goal in domestic Turkish football against [[Tuzlaspor]] in the group stage of the [[2015–16 Turkish Cup]], converting in extra time after coming on as a substitute.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fenerbahçe 1–0 Tuzlaspor|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/fenerbahce-1-0-tuzlaspor-40043589|accessdate=18 April 2016|publisher=Hurriyet|date=21 January 2016}}</ref> His season ended prematurely in February because of a hamstring injury.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pearce|first1=James|title=Lazar Markovic to miss rest of the season with hamstring injury|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/lazar-markovic-miss-rest-season-11150939|accessdate=18 April 2016|publisher=Liverpool Echo|date=7 April 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17: Loans to Sporting and Hull==== On 31 August 2016, Marković returned to [[Lisbon]] to join Benfica's [[Derby de Lisboa|local rivals]] [[Sporting CP]] on a season-long loan.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Price|first1=Glenn|title=Lazar Markovic joins Sporting Lisbon on loan from Liverpool|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/2941645/lazar-markovic-joins-sporting-lisbon-on-loan-from-liverpool|accessdate=31 August 2016|publisher=ESPN|date=31 August 2016}}</ref> He made his debut on 10 September, replacing [[Gelson Martins]] for the final 30 minutes of a 3–0 home win over [[Moreirense F.C.|Moreirense]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Celso|first1=Marcos|title=Sporting 3–0 Moreirense|url=http://www.rtp.pt/noticias/desporto/sporting-3-0-moreirense_e946373|accessdate=25 September 2016|publisher=RTP|date=10 September 2016|language=Portuguese}}</ref> and scored his first goal three weeks later on his first start to open a 3–3 draw at [[Vitória S.C.|Vitória de Guimarães]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Markovic estreia-se a titular em Guimarães|trans-title=Marković makes his first start at Guimarães|url=https://www.ojogo.pt/futebol/1a-liga/sporting/noticias/interior/markovic-estreia-se-a-titular-em-guimaraes-5419375.html|accessdate=16 October 2016|publisher=O Jogo|date=1 October 2016|language=Portuguese}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Markovic marca|trans-title=Marković scores|url=http://remate.pt/markovic-marca-guimaraes-sporting-0-1/|accessdate=16 October 2016|publisher=Remate|date=1 October 2016|language=Portuguese}}</ref>
In January 2017, Marković was recalled from his loan in Portugal and joined Premier League club [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] for the remainder of [[2016–17 Hull City A.F.C. season|the season]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Lazar Markovic: Hull sign Liverpool forward on loan for rest of season|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38720260|work=BBC Sport|date=23 January 2017|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref> He made his first Hull appearance as a 59th-minute substitute for [[Jarrod Bowen]] in a 2–1 win over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in the [[2016–17 EFL Cup]] semi-final second leg, as the ''Tigers'' lost 3–2 on aggregate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38672990|title=Hull City 2–1 Manchester United (Agg: 2–3)|date=26 January 2017|newspaper=BBC Sport|access-date=26 January 2017}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Hull by equalising in a 4–2 win at the [[KCOM Stadium]] against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on 5 April.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39426885|title=Hull City 4–2 Middlesbrough|date=5 April 2017|work=BBC Sport|access-date=6 April 2017}}</ref>
====2017–18: Loan to Anderlecht==== In January 2018, Marković again moved out on loan joining [[Belgian First Division A]] side [[R.S.C. Anderlecht]] for the second half of the 2017–18 season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Liverpool's Markovic joins Anderlecht on loan|url=https://www.itv.com/news/update/2018-01-31/liverpools-markovic-joins-anderlecht-on-loan/|website=ITV News|accessdate=3 February 2018|date=31 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Walsh|first1=Kristian|title=Lazar Markovic may have to relive Liverpool hell at Anderlecht - because of an Everton player|url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/lazar-markovic-relive-liverpool-hell-14233636|accessdate=3 February 2018|work=Liverpool Echo|date=1 February 2018}}</ref> It was admitted that upon Marković's arrival his fitness and condition was so poor that he would miss up to six weeks of game time in order to get up to standard.<ref>https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/lazar-markovic-endures-abysmal-start-12001719</ref>
===Fulham=== On 31 January 2019, Marković moved to [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on a free transfer; having only made a handful of pre-season appearances for Liverpool, since a competitive 84th-minute substitute appearance against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on 2 May 2015.<ref>https://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2019/february/01/lazar-markovic-signs</ref>
==International career== In October 2009, Marković made his [[Serbia national under-17 football team|Serbia national under-17]] debut in the qualification round for the [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]]. In May 2011, he was part of the same team at the [[2011 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]], which Serbia hosted.
Marković skipped the national under-19 selection and was immediately invited to the [[Serbia national under-21 football team|Serbian under-21 team]] for their qualification matches for the [[2013 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.smedia.rs/sport/vest/52627/ | title=Janković pozvao Lazara Markovića | language=Serbian | publisher=smedia.rs | date=28 September 2011 | accessdate=18 December 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120913203751/http://www.smedia.rs/sport/vest/52627/ | archivedate=13 September 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> He made his debut against [[Denmark national under-21 football team|Denmark]] on 11 October 2011.
On 24 February 2012, Marković was called up to the [[Serbia national football team|Serbian senior team]] for their friendly fixtures against [[Armenia national football team|Armenia]] and [[Cyprus national football team|Cyprus]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.b92.net/sport/fudbal/vesti.php?yyyy=2012&mm=02&dd=24&nav_id=585314 | title=Ćurčić zvao Markovića nije Lazovića | language=Serbian | publisher=b92.net | date=24 February 2012 | accessdate=24 February 2012}}</ref> He debuted as a starter against Armenia on 28 February 2012, three days before his 18th birthday.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.rts.rs/page/sport/sr/story/36/Fudbal/1059644/Mali%2C+malecni+korak+napred.html | title=Mali, malecni korak napred | language=Serbian | publisher=rts.rs | date=9 March 2012 | accessdate=4 June 2012}}</ref> He scored his first international goal for Serbia in a friendly match against [[Chile national football team|Chile]].<ref>{{cite web| publisher=B92| url=http://www.b92.net/sport/fudbal/vesti.php?yyyy=2012&mm=11&dd=14&nav_id=660298| title= Pobeda Srbije za kraj 2012 | date=14 November 2012| accessdate=17 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| publisher=RTS| url=http://www.rts.rs/page/sport/sr/story/36/Fudbal/1211428/Pobeda+za+ohrabrenje.html| title= Pobeda za ohrabrenje| date=14 November 2012 | accessdate=17 November 2012}}</ref>
==Personal life== Marković's older brother, [[Filip Marković|Filip]], is also a footballer. An [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]], he too came through Partizan's youth setup and currently plays in France for [[RC Lens|Lens]].<ref>[http://sport.blic.rs/Fudbal/Evropski-fudbal/234663/Nigde-bez-brata-Uz-Lazara-i-Filip-Markovic-potpisao-za-Benfiku Nigde bez brata: Uz Lazara i Filip Marković potpisao za Benfiku! (Nowhere without his brother: Lazar and Filip Marković signed for Benfica!)]; Blic Sport, 11 June 2013 (in Serbian)</ref>
