0 | club-update = 11 December 2018 | nationalteam-update = }} '''Fabricio Agosto Ramírez''' ({{IPA-es|faˈβɾiθjo aˈɣosto raˈmiɾeθ}}; born 31 December 1987), known simply as '''Fabricio''' or '''Fabri''' {{IPA-es|ˈfaβɾi|}}, is a Spanish [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Premier League]] club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]].
He appeared in 55 [[La Liga]] matches during five seasons, representing [[Deportivo de La Coruña|Deportivo]] (two spells) [[Real Valladolid|Valladolid]] and [[Real Betis|Betis]] in the competition. He also competed professionally in Turkey and England, winning the [[Süper Lig]] championship with [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]] in [[2016–17 Süper Lig|2016–17]].
==Club career== ===Spain=== Fabricio was born in [[Las Palmas]], [[Canary Islands]]. After being bought at almost 18 from local [[UD Vecindario]], he finished his football formation at [[Deportivo de La Coruña]]. After suspensions to goalkeeping teammates [[Dudu Aouate]] and [[Gustavo Munúa]] due to a post-training punching session,<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2008/SPORT/football/01/11/spain.deportivo/index.html Deportivo keepers axed after fight]; [[CNN]], 11 January 2008</ref> he was made first-choice, and made his [[La Liga]] debut on 13 January 2008 in a 3–4 away loss against [[Villarreal CF]];<ref>[http://www.marca.com/marcador/futbol/2007_08/primera/jornada_19/vil_dep/index.html Cabeza de turco blanquiazul (White-and-blue Turkish head)]; [[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]], 13 January 2008 (in Spanish)</ref> in February both offenders were reinstated in the first team, and he returned to [[Deportivo de La Coruña B|the B-squad]].
In January 2008, [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] reportedly showed interest in signing Fabri, considered "one of Spain's brightest talents".<ref>[http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11670_3046046,00.html Gunners in Depor starlet link]; [[Sky Sports]], 14 January 2008</ref> During the [[2008–09 La Liga|2008–09 season]] he was definitely promoted to backup duties as Munúa and Aouate were both deemed surplus to requirements, and also [[2008–09 Copa del Rey|appeared]] in the [[Copa del Rey]];<ref>[http://masdeporte.as.com/masdeporte/2008/11/12/polideportivo/1226543103_850215.html El Deportivo pasa y Omar Bravo se estrena como goleador (Deportivo go through and Omar Bravo gets first goal)]; [[Diario AS]], 12 November 2008 (in Spanish)</ref> however, after the [[Israel]]i's move to [[RCD Mallorca]], Munúa was again reinstated as second-choice and Fabricio returned to the reserves.
On 13 July 2009, Fabricio was released by ''Depor'', joining [[Real Valladolid]] on a 2+2 contract.<ref>[http://www.realvalladolid.es/noticias/actualidad/14072009/Fabricio-apuesta-futuro-porteria/ Fabricio, apuesta de futuro en la portería (Fabricio, bet for future in goal)]; Real Valladolid, 13 July 2009 (in Spanish)</ref> On 19 August of the following year he signed for [[Recreativo de Huelva]] in [[Segunda División|division two]], on a [[2010–11 Segunda División|one-year]] loan deal.<ref>[http://www.goal.com/es/news/21/fichajes/2010/08/19/2078362/mercado-es-oficial-el-recreativo-ficha-a-fabricio-y-descarta Mercado: Es oficial, el Recreativo ficha a Fabricio y descarta a Ibrahima (Market: It's official, Recreativo sign Fabricio and rule out Ibrahima)]; [[Goal (website)|Goal]], 19 August 2010 (in Spanish)</ref>
Fabri returned to the top flight for the [[2011–12 La Liga|2011–12 campaign]], moving to [[Real Betis]].<ref>[http://www.marca.com/2011/06/22/futbol/equipos/betis/1308748724.html Fabricio se convierte en nuevo guardameta bético (Fabricio becomes new ''bético'' goalkeeper)]; Marca, 22 June 2011 (in Spanish)</ref> He featured in 17 overall contests in his first year, keeping [[Shutout|clean sheets]] against [[Real Zaragoza]] (2–0, away),<ref>[http://www.marca.com/marcador/futbol/2011_12/primera/jornada_24/zar_bet/ El Zaragoza compra billete para el infierno (Zaragoza buy a ticket to hell)]; Marca, 20 February 2012 (in Spanish)</ref> [[Málaga CF]] (2–0, also away)<ref>[http://www.marca.com/marcador/futbol/2011_12/primera/jornada_31/mga_bet/ Excesivo castigo en La Rosaleda (Excessive punishment at La Rosaleda)]; Marca, 31 March 2012 (in Spanish)</ref> and [[CA Osasuna]] (1–0 at the ''[[Estadio Benito Villamarín]]'').<ref>[http://www.goal.com/es/match/63251/betis-vs-osasuna/report Betis 1–0 Osasuna: Rubén Castro da los tres puntos (Betis 1–0 Osasuna: Rubén Castro gives three points)]; Goal, 15 April 2012 (in Spanish)</ref> however, following a run-in with manager [[Pepe Mel]],<ref>[http://www.marca.com/2012/09/16/futbol/equipos/betis/1347790957.html Mel: "No encuentro sentido a lo que dijo Fabricio" (Mel: "I find no logic in what Fabricio said")]; Marca, 16 September 2012 (in Spanish)</ref> he was demoted to third-choice and eventually left the club in the 2013 summer, returning to Deportivo.<ref>[http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/deportivo/2013/08/17/fabricio-regresa-deportivo/00031376741714463829767.htm Fabricio regresa al Deportivo (Fabricio returns to Deportivo)]; [[La Voz de Galicia]], 17 August 2013 (in Spanish)</ref>
Fabricio played second-fiddle to [[Germán Lux]] in [[2013–14 Segunda División|his first year]] in his second spell in [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]],<ref>[http://www.marca.com/2014/06/06/futbol/equipos/deportivo/1402052029.html La afición del Dépor, pendiente de la renovación de Germán Lux (Dépor's faithful, hanging on Germán Lux's renewal)]; Marca, 6 June 2014 (in Spanish)</ref> but subsequently became the starter.<ref>[http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/deportivo/2014/10/22/espina-saco-fabricio-deportivo/00031413998327890884356.htm La «espina» que se sacó Fabricio en el Deportivo («Thorn» off Fabricio's side at Deportivo)]; La Voz de Galicia, 22 October 2014 (in Spanish)</ref> He lost the vast majority of [[2015–16 La Liga|2015–16]], however, due to a [[tibia]] injury he originally contracted ten years ago (in 2011, whilst at Betis, he also suffered a potentially career-threatening shoulder ailment).<ref>[http://www.diariodesevilla.es/article/deportes/1081980/fabricio/supera/una/lesion/comprometio/su/carrera.html Fabricio supera una lesión que comprometió su carrera (Fabricio overcomes career-threatening injury)]; Diario de Sevilla, 6 October 2011 (in Spanish)</ref><ref>[http://media.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/torremarathon/2015/12/05/diez-anos-ligamento-roto/0003_201512H5P46991.htm Diez años con el ligamento roto (Ten years with a ruptured ligament)]; La Voz de Galicia, 5 December 2015 (in Spanish)</ref>
===Beşiktaş=== In July 2016, Fabri moved abroad for the first time, signing for Turkish [[Süper Lig]] champions [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş JK]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://es.besoccer.com/noticia/fabricio-dice-adios-al-depor-para-fichar-por-el-besiktas|title=Fabricio dice adiós al Dépor para fichar por el Besiktas|trans-title=Fabricio says goodbye to Dépor to sign for Beşiktaş|publisher=Be Soccer|language=Spanish|date=10 July 2016|accessdate=2 January 2017}}</ref> In a [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|0–6 loss]] at [[FC Dynamo Kyiv]] in the [[UEFA Champions League]] group stage on 6 December, he began to cry after conceding the fourth goal of the first half.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/champions-league-besiktas-goalkeeper-cries-video-a7460781.html|title=Besiktas goalkeeper Fabricio cries after conceding four first half goals in Champions League|publisher=[[The Independent]]|last=Critchley|first=Mark|date=7 December 2016|accessdate=2 January 2017}}</ref>
In [[2016–17 Süper Lig|his first season]] in [[Istanbul]], Fabricio only missed two matches in 34 as his team were crowned champions for the second consecutive time and 15th overall.<ref name=Champion>{{cite news|url=https://www.superdeporte.es/futbol/2017/05/28/besiktas-fabricio-campeon-superliga-turca/337237.html|title=Fabricio, en la mira de La Roja, campeón con el Besiktas|trans-title=Fabricio, poised for ''La Roja'', champion with Besiktas|publisher=[[Super Deporte]]|last=Marín|first=Rafa|language=es|date=28 May 2017|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref>
===Fulham=== On 24 July 2018, Fabri joined [[Premier League]] club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on a three-year deal with the option of a fourth year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2018/july/24/fabri-confirmed|title=Fabri confirmed|publisher=Fulham F.C|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref> He was already known to their goalkeeping coach José Sambade Carreira, with the pair having worked together at Deportivo.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11681/11447362/fulham-complete-fabri-signing-from-besiktas|title=Fulham complete Fabri signing from Besiktas|publisher=Sky Sports|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref> His first appearance in the [[Premier League]] took place on 11 August, in a 0–2 home defeat against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45067373|title=Fulham 0–2 Crystal Palace|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|last=Jennings|first=Patrick|date=11 August 2018|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref>
==International career== A former [[Spain national youth football team|youth international]] for [[Spain national football team|Spain]], in February 2018 Fabri announced that he was of Uruguayan descent and wanted to represent [[Uruguay national football team|its national team]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/futbol/futbol-internacional/2018/02/14/5a842870e2704ef6498b4634.html|title=Fabricio reina en Turquía y oposita a la selección uruguaya|trans-title=Fabricio reigns in Turkey and is poised for the Uruguayan national team|publisher=Marca|language=es|date=14 February 2018|accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sabah.com.tr/spor/futbol/2018/02/15/musleraya-rakip|title=Muslera’ya rakip!|trans-title=Competing against Muslera!|publisher=[[Sabah (newspaper)|Sabah]]|language=tr|date=15 February 2018|accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref>

nationalgoals7 = 5 | club-update = 12 February 2019 | nationalteam-update = 16 November 2018 }} '''Stefan Marius Johansen''' (born 8 January 1991) is a Norwegian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on loan from [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and [[Captain (association football)|captains]] the [[Norway national football team|Norwegian national football team]].
Hailing from [[Vardø]], he joined [[FK Bodø/Glimt|Bodø/Glimt]] at the age of 14. He made his first-team debut in 2007, and transferred to [[Strømsgodset IF|Strømsgodset]] in 2011 where he was one of the key players in the team that finished second in the league in 2012 and won the league-title in 2013. Johansen won the [[Kniksen Award]] as the midfielder of the year in 2013. He transferred to Celtic in January 2014. At Celtic in 2015 he won their player of the year voted for by fans of the club.
Johansen has represented Norway at youth international level, and was a part of the [[Norway national under-21 football team|under-21 team]] at the [[2013 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2013 European Championship]]. He made his full international debut in 2013.
==Club career== ===Bodø/Glimt=== Johansen was born and raised in [[Vardø]], a small town in the far north of [[Norway]].<ref name="Strømsgodset">{{cite web |url=http://www.godset.no/player-profiles/playerID/28231 |language=Norwegian |title=Spillerprofiler – Stefan Marius Johansen |publisher=Strømsgodset IF |accessdate=3 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120912170050/http://www.godset.no/player-profiles/playerID/28231 |archivedate=12 September 2012 }}</ref><ref name="scout">{{cite web|last1=Johansen|first1=Øyvind|title=Scouting report: Stefan Johansen, Strømsgodset|url=http://www.scan-scout.com/2012/12/23/scouting-report-stefan-johansen-stromsgodset/|publisher=Scandinavian Scouting Agency|accessdate=9 February 2015|date=23 December 2012}}</ref> He moved to [[Bodø]] to sign for [[FK Bodø/Glimt|Bodø/Glimt]] at the age of 14.<ref name="Vardø-talent">{{cite news |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/troms_og_finnmark/1.7215344 |language=Norwegian |title=- TIL leder kampen om Vardø-talent |publisher=NRK |first=Ole-Marius Aune |last=Sandmo |date=19 July 2010 |accessdate=3 November 2012}}</ref> He joined the first-team squad along with [[Anders Ågnes Konradsen]] ahead of the [[2007 Norwegian First Division|2007 season]] and Johansen made his debut for the team in the First Round of the [[2007 Norwegian Football Cup]] against [[Hammerfest FK|Hammerfest]].<ref name="Strømsgodset"/> Johansen played six matches in [[Adeccoligaen]] when Bodø/Glimt was promoted to [[Tippeligaen]] in 2007, and made his debut in Tippeligaen in the 3–2 win against [[Viking FK|Viking]] on 10 August 2008<ref name="altomfotball"/> when he replaced [[Jan Derek Sørensen]] in the 85th minute.
Johansen made four appearances in the [[2009 Norwegian Premier League|2009 season]],<ref name="altomfotball"/> going on to play regularly for Bodø/Glimt in Adeccoligaen in 2010 and was regarded as one of the biggest talents in [[Northern Norway]].<ref name="Vardø-talent"/> Clubs like [[Tromsø IL|Tromsø]], [[Fredrikstad FK|Fredrikstad]] and [[Aalesunds FK|Aalesund]] wanted to sign Johansen whose contract expired after the season,<ref name="Vardø-talent"/> but he signed a three-year contract with [[Strømsgodset IF|Strømsgodset]] in December 2010, and joined the club on a free transfer on 1 January 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://dt.no/godset/stefan-johansen-klar-for-godset-1.5869511 |language=Norwegian |title=Stefan Johansen klar for Godset |publisher=Drammens Tidende |first=Magne J. |last=Nilsen |date=7 December 2010 |accessdate=3 November 2012}}</ref> Johansen played 18 matches in [[Adeccoligaen]] in his final season at Bodø/Glimt.<ref name="altomfotball"/>
===Strømsgodset=== Johansen made his debut for Strømsgodset against in the 2–1 against [[Sogndal IL|Sogndal]] when he came on in the 80th minute and replaced [[Fredrik Nordkvelle]]. In his first season at Strømsgodset, Johansen made 13 league appearances and scored one goal.<ref name="altomfotball"/> In the match against [[Sandnes Ulf]] on 16 May 2012, Johansen scored a goal from a [[Direct free kick|free kick]]. In the 5–0 win against [[Fredrikstad FK|Fredrikstad]] on 27 May 2012, Johansen scored another goal from a free kick, identical to the one he scored 11 days earlier.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tv2.no/sport/fotball/tippeligaen/stefan-johansen-med-blaakopiscoring-da-stroemsgodset-knuste-ffk-3840604.html |language=Norwegian |title=Stefan Johansen med blåkopi-scoring da Strømsgodset knuste FFK |publisher=TV2 |first=Terje |last=Skeie |date=27 May 2012 |accessdate=3 November 2012}}</ref> Johansen made his break-through at Strømsgodset after [[Mohammed Abu]] returned to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], when he became a regular in Strømsgodset's starting line-up<ref name="Strømsgodset"/><ref name="scout" /><ref>{{cite news |title=Spår duell med RBK |language=Norwegian |journal=VG Sporten |first=Jostein |last=Overvik |page=3 |date=17 May 2013}}</ref> and was in August 2012 awarded the [[Statoil]] Talent Prize for his performances.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tv2.no/sport/fotball/tippeligaen/talentpris/stefan-johansen-er-maanedens-talent-august-2012-3908488.html |language=Norwegian |title=Stefan Johansen er månedens talent – august 2012 |publisher=TV2 |first=Jonn Erik |last=Aasen |date=30 August 2012 |accessdate=3 November 2012}}</ref> In 2013, Johansen helped Stromsgodset to win their first league title for 43 years<ref name="scots" /> and was voted the [[Kniksen Award#2013|Midfielder of the Year]] in the Norwegian league.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kniksenprisen|url=http://www.toppfotball.no/kniksen-price/article/hstb2msjb5a81r20knpwd35oz/title/kniksenprisen|publisher=Norsk Toppfotball|accessdate=9 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150627093824/http://www.toppfotball.no/kniksen-price/article/hstb2msjb5a81r20knpwd35oz/title/kniksenprisen|archivedate=27 June 2015}}</ref>
===Celtic=== On 15 January 2014, Johansen sealed a move to [[Scottish Premiership]] club [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] for a transfer fee of £2 million.<ref name="scots">{{cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/spfl/stefan-johansen-signs-for-celtic-1-3268643|last=Walker|first=Mark||title=Stefan Johansen signs for Celtic|publisher=The Scotsman |date= 15 January 2014 |accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McGarry|first=John|title=Johansen's Celtic move sorted as classy Norwegian signs three-and-a-half year deal|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2539582/Stefan-Johansens-Celtic-sorted-classy-Norweigian-signs-three-half-year-deal.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490|publisher=MailOnline|accessdate=15 January 2014|date=15 January 2014}}</ref> Johansen signed a three-and-a-half-year contract with the club, and became the fourth Norwegian to play for Celtic following [[Harald Brattbakk]], [[Vidar Riseth]] and [[Thomas Rogne]].<ref name="norw">{{cite news |url=http://www.vg.no/sport/fotball/norsk/landslaget/artikkel.php?artid=10149911 |language=Norwegian |title=Johansen klar for Celtic |newspaper=Verdens Gang |first=Magnus |last=Wikan |date=15 January 2014 |accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> He was given the number 25 shirt, the same number worn in previous years by [[Ľubomír Moravčík]] and [[Shunsuke Nakamura]].<ref name="norw" />
Johansen made his debut for Celtic in the 4–0 victory against [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] on 26 January 2014 when he played the last five minutes as a substitute.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.aftenposten.no/100Sport/fotball/internasjonal/Stefan-Johansen-fikk-Celtic-debuten-414794_1.snd#.UuV_0By5T-k |language=Norwegian |title=Stefan Johansen fikk Celtic-debuten |newspaper=Aftenposten |agency=Norwegian News Agency |date=26 January 2014 |accessdate=26 January 2014}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Celtic on 22 March 2014 in a home league match against [[St Mirren F.C.|St Mirren]], opening the scoring in a 3–0 win with a header.<ref>{{cite web |last=Mackie|first=Fraser|title= Celtic 3–0 St Mirren: Hoops on brink of yet another title as Johansen nets first goal|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2586879/Celtic-3-0-St-Mirren-Hoops-brink-title-Stefan-Johansen-nets-goal.html|publisher=Daily Mail|accessdate=23 March 2014|date=22 March 2014}}</ref>
===Fulham===
Johansen signed a three-year deal with [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on 26 August 2016 for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2016/august/26/johansen-joins|title=Johansen Arrives – Fulham Football Club|date=26 August 2016|publisher=Fulham F.C.|accessdate=26 August 2016}}</ref> Johansen scored his first goal for the club in a 2–2 draw against [[Norwich City]] on 18 October 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37614928|title=Fulham 2–2 Norwich |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=18 October 2016|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref>
===West Bromwich Albion===
On 31 January 2019, Johansen joined [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Brom]] on loan until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47071573|title=West Brom: Jefferson Montero, Jacob Murphy and Stefan Johansen join on loan |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=31 January 2019|accessdate=1 February 2019}}</ref>
==International career== Johansen made his debut for Norway when he played for the under-15 team against Poland U15 on 8 August 2006.<ref name="altomfotball"/> He has later represented Norway at every level up to under-23,<ref name="nff">{{cite web |url=http://www.fotball.no/Community/Profil/?fiksId=2260004 |language=Norwegian |title=Stefan Marius Johansen's profil |work=fotball.no |publisher=[[Football Association of Norway]] |date= |accessdate=3 November 2012}}</ref> and played both matches for the [[Norway national under-21 football team|under-21 team]] when they eliminated [[France national under-21 football team|France U21]] and qualified for the [[2013 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship]].<ref name="scout" /> Johansen was part of the Norway side which beat [[England national under-21 football team|England]] in the European Under-21 Championships before losing to eventual winners [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spain]] at the semi-final stage.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Grahame|first1=Ewing|title=Celtic close in on Stromsgodset and Norway midfielder Stefan Johansen|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/celtic/10569755/Celtic-close-in-on-Stromsgodset-and-Norway-midfielder-Stefan-Johansen.html|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=9 February 2015|date=13 January 2014}}</ref>
Johansen has thirty-six full international caps for his country, scoring his first international goal on his debut against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] in [[Stockholm]] on 14 August 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stromsgodset confirm Celtic interest in midfielder Stefan Johansen|url=http://sport.stv.tv/football/clubs/celtic/259728-stromsgodset-confirm-celtic-interest-in-midfielder-stefan-johansen/|publisher=STV Sport|accessdate=9 February 2015|date=9 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Stefan Johansen|url=http://www.national-football-teams.com/player/53319/Stefan_Johansen.html|publisher=National Football Teams|accessdate=9 February 2015}}</ref>
On 22 March 2017 Johansen was appointed as the new captain of [[Norway national football team|Norway]], replacing [[Per Ciljan Skjelbred]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Stefan Johansen er Norges nye landslagskaptein|url=https://www.nrk.no/sport/stefan-johansen-er-norges-nye-landslagskaptein-1.13439728|publisher=NRK|accessdate=26 May 2018|date=22 March 2017}}</ref>

'''Fulham''' *[[EFL Championship play-offs]]: [[2018 English Football League play-offs#Championship|2018]]<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44178427 |title=Aston Villa 0–1 Fulham |first=Phil |last=Cartwright |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 May 2018 |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref>
'''Individual''' *[[Kniksen Award]], Midfielder of the Year: 2013<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/spfl/stefan-johansen-arctic-circle-to-champions-league-1-3270198 |title=Stefan Johansen: Arctic Circle to Champions League |publisher=}}</ref> *Norwegian Player of the Year: 2014<ref name=2014_tippeligaen_ypoty>{{cite web |title=Stefan Johansen vant gullballen|trans-title=Stefan Johansen won the Golden Ball |url=http://www.toppfotball.no/news/article/ujunc3q4y7f1rcz07oyvksig/title/stefan-johansen-fikk-gullballen-2014/ |website=toppfotball.no |publisher=Norsk Toppfotball |accessdate=10 November 2014 |language=Norwegian |date=10 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141111003406/http://www.toppfotball.no/news/article/ujunc3q4y7f1rcz07oyvksig/title/stefan-johansen-fikk-gullballen-2014/ |archivedate=11 November 2014}}</ref> *[[PFA Scotland Players' Player of the Year]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Portuguese name|da Rocha|Fonte}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Rui Fonte |image = Rui Fonte, Fulham FC (35911422634).jpg |image_size = 200 |caption = Fonte playing for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in 2017 |fullname = Rui Pedro da Rocha Fonte<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.efl.com/siteassets/efl-documents/efl-professional-retain-list--free-transfers---2017-18.pdf|title=Club list of registered players: As at 19th May 2018: Fulham|publisher=English Football League|page=16|format=PDF|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1990|4|23|df=y}}<ref name=Soccerway/> |birth_place = [[Lisbon]], Portugal |height = 1.81 m<ref name=Soccerway/> |position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]], [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] |currentclub = [[Lille OSC|Lille]] (on loan from [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]) |clubnumber = 10 |youthyears1 = 1998–1999 | youthclubs1 = Sacavenense |youthyears2 = 1999–2006 | youthclubs2 = [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting CP]] |youthyears3 = 2006–2009 | youthclubs3 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] |years1 = 2008–2009 | clubs1 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 |years2 = 2009 | clubs2 = → [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] (loan) | caps2 = 10 | goals2 = 0 |years3 = 2009–2011 | clubs3 = [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting CP]] | caps3 = 0 | goals3 = 0 |years4 = 2009–2010 | clubs4 = → [[Vitória F.C.|Vitória Setúbal]] (loan) | caps4 = 13 | goals4 = 0 |years5 = 2010–2011 | clubs5 = → [[RCD Espanyol B|Espanyol B]] (loan) | caps5 = 22 | goals5 = 8 |years6 = 2010–2011 | clubs6 = → [[RCD Espanyol|Espanyol]] (loan) | caps6 = 11 | goals6 = 0 |years7 = 2011–2013 | clubs7 = [[RCD Espanyol|Espanyol]] | caps7 = 29 | goals7 = 1 |years8 = 2013–2015 | clubs8 = [[S.L. Benfica B|Benfica B]] | caps8 = 26 | goals8 = 18 |years9 = 2013–2016 | clubs9 = [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] | caps9 = 0 | goals9 = 0 |years10 = 2015 | clubs10 = → [[C.F. Os Belenenses|Belenenses]] (loan) | caps10 = 12 | goals10 = 2 |years11 = 2015–2016 | clubs11 = → [[S.C. Braga|Braga]] (loan) | caps11 = 15 | goals11 = 4 |years12 = 2016–2017 | clubs12 = [[S.C. Braga|Braga]] | caps12 = 28 | goals12 = 13 |years13 = 2017– | clubs13 = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] | caps13 = 27 | goals13 = 3 |years14 = 2018– | clubs14 = → [[Lille OSC|Lille]] (loan) | caps14 = 3 | goals14 = 0 |totalcaps = | totalgoals = |nationalyears1 = 2005–2006 | nationalteam1 = [[Portugal national under-16 football team|Portugal U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 12 | nationalgoals1 = 3 |nationalyears2 = 2006–2007 | nationalteam2 = [[Portugal national under-17 football team|Portugal U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 13 | nationalgoals2 = 2 |nationalyears3 = 2008 | nationalteam3 = [[Portugal national under-18 football team|Portugal U18]] | nationalcaps3 = 5 | nationalgoals3 = 3 |nationalyears4 = 2008–2009 | nationalteam4 = [[Portugal national under-19 football team|Portugal U19]] | nationalcaps4 = 12 | nationalgoals4 = 8 |nationalyears5 = 2010 | nationalteam5 = [[Portugal national under-20 football team|Portugal U20]] | nationalcaps5 = 5 | nationalgoals5 = 2 |nationalyears6 = 2008–2012 | nationalteam6 = [[Portugal national under-21 football team|Portugal U21]] | nationalcaps6 = 22 | nationalgoals6 = 8 |club-update = 10:36, 11 October 2018 (UTC) |nationalteam-update = }} '''Rui Pedro da Rocha Fonte''' (born 23 April 1990) is a Portuguese professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] or a [[Midfielder#Winger|right winger]] for French club [[Lille OSC]] on loan from [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].
After signing for [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] as a 16-year-old, he only made one competitive appearance for the club before signing with [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting]], who loaned him several times for the duration of his contract, including at [[RCD Espanyol|Espanyol]] who acquired him permanently in 2011. He subsequently joined [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]], where injury problems saw him feature sparingly until his release; with his next team, [[S.C. Braga|Braga]], he notably won the [[2016 Taça de Portugal Final|2016 Portuguese Cup]].
All youth levels comprised, Fonte earned 69 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] for [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]], scoring 26 goals.
==Club career== ===Early years / Arsenal=== Fonte was born in [[Lisbon]],<ref>{{Hugman|23066|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref> and joined [[Sporting Clube de Portugal]]'s youth system at only nine. In 2006 he signed a three-year contract with [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], with a clause stating he was to return to his previous club if the English did not extend the contract beyond the original period.
A regular member of Arsenal's [[Arsenal F.C. Reserves|reserves]], Fonte made his debut for the first team in a [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly]] against [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] in the 2008 pre-season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/match/report/0809//first-team/barnet-1-2-arsenal-picture-gallery|title=Barnet 1–2 Arsenal|publisher=Arsenal F.C.|date=19 July 2008|accessdate=19 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019171026/http://www.arsenal.com/match/report/0809//first-team/barnet-1-2-arsenal-picture-gallery|archivedate=19 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He made his competitive debut for the Gunners as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Carlos Vela]] in a [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] match against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on 11 November 2008, a [[2008–09 Football League Cup|3–0 home win]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/match/report/0809/post/first-team/arsenal-3-0-wigan-athletic-match-report|title=Arsenal 3–0 Wigan Athletic|publisher=Arsenal F.C|first=Chris|last=Harris|date=11 November 2008|accessdate=19 October 2013}}</ref>
On 30 January 2009, Fonte signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] side [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on a one-month loan, with his older brother [[José Fonte|José]] playing a big role in persuading club and player of each other's merits.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crystal_palace/7861771.stm|title=Palace sign Arsenal striker Fonte|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=30 January 2009|accessdate=31 January 2009}}</ref> He made his debut for his new team in a 0–1 home defeat to [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on the following day,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7856654.stm|title=Crystal Palace 0–1 Blackpool|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 January 2009|accessdate=31 January 2009}}</ref> and his loan was subsequently extended until the end of the season;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crystal_palace/7929365.stm|title=Crystal Palace extend Fonte loan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 March 2009|accessdate=27 March 2009}}</ref> Palace were docked a point and fined £20,000 for fielding him in their final match, despite his loan having expired.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/jun/01/crystal-palace-point-deducted-rui-fonte|title=Crystal Palace have one point deducted for fielding ineligible Rui Fonte|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=1 June 2009|accessdate=3 September 2017}}</ref>
On 19 May 2009, it was announced that Arsenal had decided not to extend Fonte's three-year contract, and the player returned to Sporting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-sporting-news/1564-rui-fonte-returns-to-sporting|title=Rui Fonte returns to Sporting|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=19 May 2009|accessdate=19 May 2009}}</ref> He spent the [[2009–10 Primeira Liga|2009–10 campaign]] on loan to [[Vitória F.C.|Vitória de Setúbal]], making his [[Primeira Liga]] debut on 17 August in a 0–0 home draw against [[Vitória S.C.|Vitória de Guimarães]] (one minute played)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://desporto.sapo.cv/futebol/jogo/v-setubal-vs-v-guimaraes-62843|title=V. Setúbal 0–0 V. Guimarães|publisher=[[SAPO (company)|SAPO]]|language=Portuguese|date=17 August 2009|accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref> and appearing sparingly during the campaign as the former barely escaped relegation.
===Espanyol=== Fonte played [[2010–11 La Liga|2010–11]] on loan to [[RCD Espanyol]], in Spain. He spent the vast majority of his spell with [[RCD Espanyol B|the reserves]], his first [[La Liga]] appearances consisting of one minute in a 1–0 home win over [[Sporting de Gijón]] on 5 December 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/en/report/301850/report.html?soccernet=true|title=Garcia rescues Espanyol|publisher=[[ESPN FC|ESPN Soccernet]]|date=5 December 2010|accessdate=19 October 2013}}</ref> and ten in a 0–1 loss to [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] also at the ''[[RCDE Stadium|Estadi Cornellà-El Prat]]'', two months later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/en/report/301979/report.html?soccernet=true|title=Ten-man Real grind out win|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|date=13 February 2011|accessdate=19 October 2013}}</ref>
On 14 July 2011, Fonte signed permanently for Espanyol for two years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fichajes.net/noticias/firma-por-dos-a%C3%B1os-20110714.html|title=Firma por dos años|trans-title=Signs for two years|publisher=Fichajes|language=Spanish|date=14 July 2011|accessdate=19 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2011/07/14/mas_futbol/1310594428_850215.html|title=Rui Fonte: "Estoy feliz por firmar por dos años"|trans-title=Rui Fonte: "I am happy to have signed for two years"|newspaper=[[Diario AS]]|language=Spanish|date=14 July 2011|accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref> On 17 January of the following year he scored his first official goal for the ''Pericos'', in a 3–2 home win against [[CD Mirandés]] for [[2011–12 Copa del Rey|the quarter-finals]] of the [[Copa del Rey]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/marcador/futbol/2011_12/copa/cuartos/ida/esp_mir/|title=Asalto frustrado a Cornellá|trans-title=Frustrated assault on Cornellá|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=Spanish|date=17 January 2012|accessdate=19 January 2012}}</ref>– he also netted in the second leg, albeit in a 1–2 and 4–4 aggregate loss;<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/marcador/futbol/2011_12/copa/cuartos/vuelta/mir_esp/|title=El milagro de Anduva|trans-title=Miracle in Anduva|newspaper=Marca|language=Spanish|date=24 January 2012|accessdate=24 January 2012}}</ref> in between he scored his first goal in the league, closing the scoresheet in a 3–0 home success over [[Granada CF]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/en/report/325241/report.html?soccernet=true|title=Baena sets Espanyol on their way|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|date=21 January 2012|accessdate=24 January 2012}}</ref>
===Benfica=== On 29 January 2013, Fonte terminated his contract with Espanyol and, on the next day, signed with [[S.L. Benfica]] on a five-and-a-half-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/espanha/benfica-rui-fonte-espanhol-rescisao-contrato/1414618-1486.html|title=Oficial: Rui Fonte rescindiu com o Espanhol|trans-title=Official: Rui Fonte cut ties with Espanyol|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=Portuguese|date=29 January 2013|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Nacional/1a_liga/Benfica//interior.aspx?content_id=801929|title=Rui Fonte assina por cinco épocas e meia|trans-title=Rui Fonte signs for five and a half seasons|newspaper=[[Record (newspaper)|Record]]|language=Portuguese|date=30 January 2013|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> He was initially assigned to [[S.L. Benfica B|the B-team]] in the [[LigaPro|Segunda Liga]], suffering a knee injury in his debut against [[C.F. União]] and being sidelined for the rest of [[2012–13 Segunda Liga|the campaign]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://desporto.sapo.pt/futebol/segunda-liga/artigos/rui-fonte-so-regressa-na-proxima-epoca|title=Rui Fonte só regressa na próxima época|trans-title=Rui Fonte only returns the next season|publisher=SAPO|language=Portuguese|date=6 February 2013|accessdate=21 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2013/02/06/primera/1360163468_539730.html|title=Rui Fonte, cinco meses de baja tras lesionarse en una rodilla|trans-title=Rui Fonte, five months out after injuring knee|newspaper=Diario AS|language=Spanish|date=6 February 2013|accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref>
In January 2015, [[Jorge Jesus]] confirmed that Fonte was promoted to Benfica's first team after the loan of [[Nélson Oliveira]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slbenfica.pt/noticias/detalhedenoticia/tabid/2788/ArticleId/40085/language/pt-PT/Jorge-Jesus-Homenagear-Eusebio-pela-referencia-que-foi.aspx|title=Jorge Jesus: "Homenagear Eusébio pela referência que foi"|trans-title=Jorge Jesus: "Pay hommage to Eusébio for the reference he was"|publisher=S.L. Benfica|language=Portuguese|date=9 January 2015|accessdate=9 January 2015}}</ref> His first competitive appearance took place on the 14th, as he played the first half of the 4–0 home win against [[F.C. Arouca]] for [[2014–15 Taça da Liga|the third round]] of the [[Taça da Liga]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.dn.pt/desporto/benfica/interior/benfica-goleia-arouca-na-taca-da-liga-4342595.html|title=Benfica goleia Arouca na Taça da Liga|trans-title=Benfica rout Arouca in League Cup|newspaper=[[Diário de Notícias]]|language=Portuguese|date=14 January 2015|accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref>
On 2 February 2015, Fonte, at the time second level top scorer for Benfica B with 17 goals in 21 matches,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/liga-nos/detalhe/rui-fonte-e-goncalo-paciencia-o-europeu-em-ponto-de-mira-966815.html|title=Rui Fonte e Gonçalo Paciência: O Europeu em ponto de mira|trans-title=Rui Fonte and Gonçalo Paciência: Sights set on European Championships|newspaper=Record|language=Portuguese|date=4 August 2015|accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref> was loaned to [[C.F. Os Belenenses]], until the end of [[2014–15 Primeira Liga|the season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ligaportugal.pt/media/51916/listagem-registo-contratos-dia-02-02-2015.pdf|title=Contratos de trabalho desportivo e contratos de formação desportiva recepcionados na Liga Portugal dia 02 de Fevereiro de 2015|trans-title=Sporting work contracts and sporting training contracts registered at Liga Portugal on 02 February 2015|publisher=[[Liga Portuguesa de Futebol Profissional]]|language=Portuguese|date=2 February 2015|accessdate=3 February 2015|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203124958/http://www.ligaportugal.pt/media/51916/listagem-registo-contratos-dia-02-02-2015.pdf|archivedate=3 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abola.pt/nnh/ver.aspx?id=528461|title=Rui é reforço|trans-title=Rui Fonte is an addition|newspaper=[[A Bola]]|language=Portuguese|date=3 February 2015|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> For [[2015–16 Primeira Liga|2015–16]], in the same predicament, he joined [[S.C. Braga]] also in the top level.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scbraga.pt/news/futebol/rui-fonte-reforca-o-sc-braga|title=Rui Fonte reforça o plantel do SC Braga|trans-title=Rui Fonte strengthens SC Braga squad|publisher=S.C. Braga|language=Portuguese|date=30 July 2015|access-date=30 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150730161649/http://www.scbraga.pt/news/futebol/rui-fonte-reforca-o-sc-braga|archivedate=30 July 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Braga=== On 16 December 2015, after having replaced [[Wilson Eduardo]] for the last 11 minutes of regulation time, Fonte scored the 4–3 winner for the hosts against Sporting, helping [[2015–16 Taça de Portugal|oust]] his former club from the [[Taça de Portugal]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://expresso.sapo.pt/desporto/2015-12-16-Taca-Braga-deixa-Sporting-para-tras|title=Taça: Braga deixa Sporting para trás|trans-title=Cup: Braga leave Sporting behind|newspaper=[[Expresso (newspaper)|Expresso]]|language=Portuguese|date=16 December 2015|accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref> The following 22 May, after being injured for nearly three months,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scbraga.pt/rui-fonte-e-pedro-santos-regressam/|title=Rui Fonte e Pedro Santos regressam|trans-title=Rui Fonte and Pedro Santos return|publisher=S.C. Braga|language=Portuguese|date=14 May 2016|accessdate=23 May 2016}}</ref> he started in [[2016 Taça de Portugal Final|the final of the domestic cup]], netting in a 2–2 draw against [[FC Porto]] (4–2 [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] win).<ref name=RR>{{cite web|url=https://rr.sapo.pt/noticia/54785/sp_braga_vence_taca_de_portugal|title=Sp. Braga vence Taça de Portugal|trans-title=Sp. Braga win Portuguese Cup|publisher=[[Rádio Renascença]]|language=Portuguese|date=22 May 2016|accessdate=22 May 2016}}</ref>
On 1 September 2016, Fonte signed a three-year contract with Braga.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scbraga.pt/rui-fonte-e-reforco-do-sc-braga/|title=Rui Fonte é reforço do SC Braga|trans-title=Rui Fonte is a SC Braga addition|publisher=S.C. Braga|language=Portuguese|date=1 September 2016|accessdate=1 September 2016}}</ref> He scored 11 goals during [[2016–17 Primeira Liga|the campaign]] (15 overall), helping to a fifth-place finish.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://desporto.sapo.pt/futebol/primeira-liga/artigos/rui-fonte-quer-marcar-mais-golos-do-que-no-ano-passado|title=Rui Fonte quer marcar mais golos do que no ano passado|trans-title=Rui Fonte wants to score more goals than last year|publisher=SAPO|language=Portuguese|date=30 June 2017|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref>
===Fulham=== On 17 August 2017, Fonte transferred to Championship club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] after agreeing to a three-year contract.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2017/august/17/fonte-joins|title=Fonte joins|publisher=Fulham F.C|date=17 August 2017|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> He scored in his second league appearance, a 2–0 away win over [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40983498|title=Ipswich Town 0–2 Fulham|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 August 2017|accessdate=27 August 2017}}</ref>
On 31 August 2018, Fonte joined [[Lille OSC]] from France on a [[2018–19 Ligue 1|season]]-long loan, reuniting with his older brother [[José Fonte]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.losc.fr/actualites-foot-lille/un-renfort-offensif-nomm%C3%A9-rui-fonte|title=Un renfort offensif nommé Rui Fonte|trans-title=An attacking addition named Rui Fonte|publisher=Lille OSC|language=French|date=31 August 2018|accessdate=31 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11813/11487322/rui-fonte-joins-lille-from-fulham-on-season-loan|title=Rui Fonte joins Lille from Fulham on season loan|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=31 August 2018|accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Fonte made his debut for the [[Portugal national under-21 football team|Portugal under-21s]] against [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spain]] on 18 November 2008, scoring the first goal in a 4–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/news/newsid=775935.html|title=Portugal plunder Iberian bragging rights|publisher=UEFA|date=18 November 2008|accessdate=19 October 2013}}</ref> He was called up to the full side for the first time on 31 March 2015 for a friendly with [[Cape Verde national football team|Cape Verde]], remaining on the bench in the 0–2 defeat in [[Estoril]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/32140214|title=Portugal 0–2 Cape Verde Islands|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 March 2015|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Fonte's older brother, [[José Fonte|José]], is also a footballer – a [[Defender (association football)|defender]], he played most of his professional career in England, and the two were teammates at Sporting (youth), Crystal Palace and Lille.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crystal_palace/7861771.stm|title=Palace sign Arsenal striker Fonte|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 January 2009|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref>
Their father, [[Artur Fonte|Artur]], played 12 seasons in the Portuguese top division.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/figura-da-jornada/belenenses/rui-fonte-so-precisa-de-confianca-para-abrir-o-livro|title=Rui Fonte só "precisa de confiança para abrir o livro"|trans-title=Rui Fonte only «needs confidence to open the book»|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=Portuguese|date=17 February 2015|accessdate=24 April 2017}}</ref>

{{Infobox football biography |name = Aboubakar Kamara |image = Aboubakar Kamara, Fulham FC.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Kamara playing for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in 2017 |fullname = Aboubakar Kamara{{cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/siteassets/efl-documents/efl-professional-retain-list--free-transfers---2017-18.pdf |title=Club list of registered players: As at 19th May 2018: Fulham |publisher=English Football League |format=PDF |page=16 |accessdate=17 June 2018}} |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1995|3|7|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Gonesse]], France |height = 1.77 m |position = [[Forward (association football)|Striker]] |currentclub = [[Yeni Malatyaspor|Yeni Malatyaspor]]
(on loan from [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]) |clubnumber = 47 |youthyears1 = {{0|0000}}–2014 |youthclubs1 = [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] |years1 = 2013–2015 |clubs1 = [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco B]] |caps1 = 26 |goals1 = 15 |years2 = 2014–2015 |clubs2 = [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] |caps2 = 2 |goals2 = 0 |years3 = 2015–2016 |clubs3 = [[K.V. Kortrijk|Kortrijk]] |caps3 = 12 |goals3 = 0 |years4 = 2016–2017 |clubs4 = [[Amiens SC|Amiens]] |caps4 = 45 |goals4 = 15 |years5 = 2016–2017 |clubs5 = [[Amiens SC|Amiens B]] |caps5 = 1 |goals5 = 0 |clubs6 = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] |years6 = 2017– |caps6 = 45 |goals6 = 10 |clubs7 = → [[Yeni Malatyaspor|Yeni Malatyaspor]] (loan) |years7 = 2019– |caps7 = 0 |goals7 = 0 |club-update = 17:11, 31 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Aboubakar Kamara''' (born 7 March 1995) is a French professional footballer who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|striker]] for [[Süper Lig]] club [[Yeni Malatyaspor|Yeni Malatyaspor]], on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/aboubakar-kamara/324040/|title=France – A. Kamara – Profile with news, career statistics and history – Soccerway|publisher=soccerway.com|accessdate=2014-10-05}} ==Career== Kamara made his [[Ligue 1]] debut for [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] on 12 September 2014 against [[Olympique Lyonnais]] in a 2–1 away defeat. He replaced [[Yannick Carrasco]] after 84 minutes.{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/09/12/france/ligue-1/olympique-lyonnais/association-sportive-monaco-fc/1686787/|title=Lyon vs. Monaco – 12 September 2014 – Soccerway|publisher=soccerway.com|accessdate=2014-10-05}} On July 2015, Kamara signed a three-year contract with [[Belgian Pro League]] side [[K.V. Kortrijk]],{{cite web|title=KV Kortrijk trekt aanvaller van AS Monaco aan|url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/sportwereld/cnt/dmf20150706_01764473|website=nieuwsblad.be|publisher=nieuwsblad|accessdate=8 September 2015|language=French|date=6 July 2015}} but returned to France only six months later, joining [[Championnat National]] side [[Amiens SC|Amiens]] and helping the club to achieve back-to-back promotions up to [[Ligue 1]].https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/FootballFicheJoueur50513.htmlhttps://www.goal.com/en/news/strasbourg-amiens-promoted-ligue-1-finale/e1sa45mfsqqj1e1atfw2dz9qi Kamara scored the first goal of a dramatic 2-1 win against [[Stade de Reims]] in the last matchday, with Amiens clinching promotion after retaking the lead in the 6th minute of the stoppage time.https://www.goal.com/en-tza/match/reims-v-amiens-sc/lineups/bgw7mnm8l1k5uplbpa4r0hre1 Kamara ended the season as the club's top goalscorer at the [[2016–17 Ligue 2]] with 10 goals.https://www.lfp.fr/ligue2/classementButeurs#sai=100&journee1=1&journee2=38&cat=G&poste=Tous ===Fulham=== On 31 July 2017, Kamara signed for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] for an undisclosed fee on a four-year contract with an option for another 12 months.{{cite web|url=https://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2017/july/31/kamara-signs|title=Kamara Signs|website=www.fulhamfc.com|date=31 July 2017|accessdate=31 July 2017}} He chose to wear the number 47 so that his initials and number would match [[AK-47]].https://www.sofoot.com/aboubakar-kamara-appelez-le-ak-47-446357.html On 23 September, Kamara scored his first goal for the club in a 1–1 draw against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41289622|title=Fulham 1–1 Middlesbrough|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 September 2017|accessdate=2 January 2019}} and three days later, he scored the opening goal in a 3–1 win over [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41315214|title=Nottingham Forest 1–3 Fulham|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 September 2017|accessdate=2 January 2019}} On 31 October, he was sent off for shoving [[Bailey Wright]] off the ball, as Fulham lost 2–0 to [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41730389|title=Fulham 0–2 Bristol City|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 October 2017|accessdate=2 January 2019}} He later scored consecutive braces for Fulham in a 2–2 draw with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] and in a 4–1 win over [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42463026|title=Hull City 2–2 Fulham|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 December 2017|accessdate=2 January 2019}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42481346|title=Fulham 4–1 Ipswich Town|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 January 2017|accessdate=2 January 2019}} On 20 January 2018, he scored the final goal in a 6–0 win over [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42671844|title=Fulham 6–0 Burton Albion|publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 January 2018|accessdate=2 January 2019}} This turned out to be the last goal he scored for Fulham during the 2017–18 season, as he was used sparingly afterwards, with the rest of his appearances coming off the bench. On 5 December, Kamara scored his first goal of the 2018–19 season in a 1–1 draw against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46367297|title=Fulham 1–1 Leicester City|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 December 2018|accessdate=2 January 2019}} and three days later, he scored a consolation penalty in a 4–1 loss to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], after coming on at half-time for [[Aleksandar Mitrović (footballer)|Aleksandar Mitrović]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46409331|title=Manchester United 4–1 Fulham|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 December 2018|accessdate=2 January 2019}} On 29 December, against [[Huddersfield Town F.C.|Huddersfield Town]], Kamara argued with Mitrović over taking a penalty; his effort was saved by [[Jonas Lössl]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46656880|title=Fulham 1–0 Huddersfield Town|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 December 2018|accessdate=2 January 2019}} Although Fulham won the match, manager [[Claudio Ranieri]] was angered by Kamara's decision to take the penalty, stating: "He did not respect me, the club, team-mates and crowd. I spoke with him, it is not right". Mitrović was more forgiving of Kamara, referring to a similar incident he had while playing for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46711004|title=Claudio Ranieri says he 'wanted to kill' Aboubakar Kamara|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 December 2018|accessdate=2 January 2019}} On New Year's Day, Kamara scored against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], in a eventual 4–1 loss.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46677557|title=Arsenal 4–1 Fulham|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 January 2018|accessdate=2 January 2019}} During January, Kamara had another altercation with Mitrović in a yoga session at the club's training ground, and as a result, was left out of the team squad for Fulham's match against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11681/11607867/fulhams-aleksandar-mitrovic-and-aboubakar-kamara-in-gym-bust-up|title=Fulham's Aleksandar Mitrovic and Aboubakar Kamara in gym bust-up|publisher=Sky Sports|date=15 January 2019|accessdate=23 January 2019}}{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11681/11610910/aleksandar-mitrovic-and-aboubakar-kamara-bust-up-played-down-by-claudio-ranieri|title=Aleksandar Mitrovic and Aboubakar Kamara bust-up played down by Claudio Ranieri|publisher=Sky Sports|date=18 January 2019|accessdate=23 January 2019}} Later that month, Kamara was arrested at the club's training ground on suspicion of [[Assault occasioning actual bodily harm|actual bodily harm]] and [[Criminal damage in English law|criminal damage]],{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2019/jan/23/fulham-aboubakar-kamara-arrested-on-suspicion-of-actual-bodily-harm|title=Fulham’s Aboubakar Kamara arrested on suspicion of actual bodily harm|work=The Guardian|first=Sachin|last=Nakrani|date=23 January 2019|accessdate=23 January 2019}} and was "banned indefinitely from all club activities".{{cite news|title=Aboubakar Kamara: Fulham striker arrested on suspicion of ABH and criminal damage |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46978891|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 January 2019|accessdate=23 January 2019}} ====Yeni Malatyaspor (loan)==== Kamara had been training with the under-23 squad, and, on 31 January 2019, joined [[Yeni Malatyaspor]] on loan until the end of the season.{{cite news |title=Aboubakar Kamara: Fulham striker loaned to Turkish club Yeni Malatyaspor |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47077017 |accessdate=31 January 2019}} ==Honours== '''Fulham''' *[[EFL Championship play-offs]]: [[2018 English Football League play-offs#Championship|2018]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44178427 |title=Aston Villa 0–1 Fulham |first=Phil |last=Cartwright |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 May 2018 |accessdate=26 May 2018}} ==Personal life== Kamara was born in France and is of Mauritanian descent.{{cite web|url=https://www.chezvlane.com/Aboubakar-Kamara-a-rencontre-Corentin-Martins-le-selectionneur-de-la-Mauritanie_a1229.html|title=Aboubakar Kamara a rencontré Corentin Martins, le sélectionneur de la
